div1.head: The Actors.
div1.p: Lycas ser. to the widow Countess.
3. Lords suitors to Eudora the widow Countess.
Hyl. Nephew to Tharsalio, and Son to Lysander.

div1.stage: Tharsalio Solus, with a Glass in his hand making ready.

sp.l: Thou blind imperfect Goddess, that delights
(Like a deep reaching Statesman) to converse
Only with Fools: Jealous of knowing spirits;
For fear their piercing Judgments might discover
Thy inward weakness, and despise thy power;
Contemn thee for a Goddess; Thou that leddest
The unworthy Ass with gold; while worth and merit
Serve thee for nought; (weak Fortune) I renounce
Thy vain dependence, and convert my duty
And sacrifices of my sweetest thoughts,
To a more Noble Deity. Sole friend to worth,
And Patroness of all good Spirits, Confidence .
She be my Guide, and hers the praise of these
My worthy undertakings.

div1.stage: Enter Lysander with a Glass in his hand, Cynthia, Hylus, Ero.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Morrow Brother; Not ready yet?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: No; I have somewhat of the Brother in me; I dare say, your Wife is many times ready, and you not up . Save you sister; how, are you enamoured of my presence? how like you my aspect?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Faith no worse than I did last week, the weather has nothing changed the grain of your complexion.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A firm proof, it is in grain, and so are not all complexions.
A good Soldiers face Sister.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Made to be worn under a Beaver.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Aye , and it would show well enough under a mask too.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: So much for the face.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: But is there no object in this suite to whet your tongue upon ?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: None, but Fortune send you well to wear it: for she best knows how you got it.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Faith, it is the portion she bestows upon younger Brothers, valour, and good clothes: Marry, if you ask how we come by this new suite, I must take time to answer it: for as the Ballad says, in written Books I find it. Brother these are the blossoms of spirit: and I will have it said for my Fathers honour, that some of his children were truly begotten.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Not all?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Shall I tell you brother that I know will rejoice you? my former suites have been all spenders, this shall be a speeder.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: A thing to be heartily wished; but brother, take heed you be not gulled, be not too forward.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: It had been well for me, if you had followed that counsel: You were too forward when you stepped into the world before me, and gulled me of the Land, that my spirits and parts were indeed borne too.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: May we not have the blessing to know the aim of your fortunes, what coast, for heavens love ?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Nay, it is a project of State: you may see the preparation; but the design lies hidden in the breasts of the wise.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: May we not know it?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Not unless you will promise me to laugh at it, for without your applause, I will none.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: The quality of it may be such as a laugh will not be ill bestowed upon it ; pray heaven I call not Arsace sister.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: What? the Panderess?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Know you (as who knows not) the exquisite Lady of the Palace? The late Governors admired Widow? The rich and haughty Countess Eudora? Were not she a Jewel worth the wearing, if a man knew how to win her?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: How is that? how is that?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Brother, there is a certain Goddess called Confidence , that carries a maine stroke in honourable preferments. Fortune waits upon her; Cupid is at her beck; she sends them both of errands. This Deity doth promise me much assistance in this business.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: But if this Deity should draw you up in a basket to your Countesses window, and there let you hang for all the wits in the Town to shoot at: how then?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: If she do, let them shoot their bolts and spare not: I have a little Bird in a Cage here that sings me better comfort. What should be the bar? you will say, I was Page to the Count her husband. What of that? I have thereby one foot in her favour already; She has taken note of my spirit, and surveyed my good parts, and the picture of them lives in her eye: which sleep, I know, cannot close, till she have embraced the substance.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: All this savours of the blind Goddess you speak of.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Why should I despair, but that Cupid hath one dart in store for her great Ladyship, as well as for any other huge Lady, whom she hath made stoop Gallant, to kiss their worthy followers. In a word, I am assured of my speed. Such fair attempts led by a brave resolve, are evermore seconded by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: But brother? have I not heard you say, your own ears have been witness to her vows, made solemnly to your late Lord; in memory of him, to preserve till death, the unstained honour of a Widows bed. If nothing else, yet that might cool your confidence.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Tush sister, suppose you should protest with solemn oath (as perhaps you have done, if ever Heaven hears your prayers, that you may live to see my Brother nobly interred) to feed only upon fish, and not endure the touch of flesh, during the wretched Lent of your miserable life; would you believe it Brother?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: I am therein most confident.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Indeed, you had better believe it than try it: but pray Sister tell me, you are a woman: do not you wives nod your heads, and smile one upon another when ye meet abroad?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Smile? why so?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: As who should say, are not we mad Wenches, that can lead our blind husbands thus by the noses? do you not brag amongst yourselves how grossly you abuse their honest credulities? how they adore you for Saints: and you believe it? while you adorn their temples, and they believe it not? how you vow Widowhood in their lifetime, and they believe you, when even in the sight of their breathless corse, ere they be fully cold, you join embraces with his Groom, or his Physician, and perhaps his poisoner; or at least by the next Moon (if you can expect so long) solemnly plight new Hymine all bonds, with a wild, confident, untamed Ruffian?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: As for example.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And make him the top of his house, and sovereign Lord of the Palace, as for example. Look you Brother, this glass is mine.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: While I am with it, it takes impression from my face; but can I make it so mine, that it shall be of no use to any other? will it not do his office to you or you: and as well to my Groom as to myself? Brother, Monopolies are cried down. Is it not madness for me to believe, when I have conquered that Fort of chastity the great Countess; that if another man of my making, and metal, shall assault her: her eyes and ears should lose their function, her other parts their use, as if Nature had made her all in vain, unless I only had stumbled into her quarters.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Brother: I fear me in your travail, you have drunk too much of that Italian air, that hath infected the whole mass of your ingenuous Nature; dried up in you all sap of generous disposition, poisoned the very Essence of your soul, and so polluted your senses, that whatsoever, enters there, takes from them contagion, and is to your fancy represented as foul and tainted, which in itself perhaps is spotless.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: No sister, it hath refined my senses, and made me see with clear eyes, and to judge of objects, as they truly are, not as they seem, and through their mask to discern the true face of things. It tells me how short-lived Widows tears are, that their weeping is in truth but laughing under a Mask, that they mourn in their Gowns, and laugh in their Sleeves, all which I believe as a Delphian Oracle: and am resolved to burn in that faith, And in that resolution do I march to the great Lady.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: You lose time Brother in discourse, by this had you bore up with the Lady and clapped her aboard, for I know your confidence will not dwell long in the service.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: No, I will perform it in the Conquerors style. Your way is, not to win Penelope by suite, but by surprise. The Castle is carried by a sudden assault, that would perhaps sit out a twelve-months siege. It would be a good breeding to my young Nephew here, if he could procure a stand at the Palace, to see with what alacrity I will accost her Countship, in what garb I will woo her, with what facility I will win her.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p:
It shall go hard but we will hear your entertainment
for your confidence sake.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: And having won her Nephew; This sweet face
Which all the City says, is so like me,
Like me shall be preferred, for I will wed thee
To my great widows Daughter and sole Heir,
The lovely spark, the bright Laodice.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: A good pleasant dream.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: In this eye I see
That fire that shall in me inflame the Mother,
And that in this shall set on fire the Daughter.
It goes Sir in a blood; believe me brother,
These destinies go ever in a blood.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: These diseases do, brother, take heed of them:
Fare you well; Take heed you be not baffled.

div1.stage: Exeunt. Lys. Cynth. Hyl. Ero. manet Thars.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Now thou that art the third blind Deity
That governs earth in all her happiness,
The life of all endowments, Confidence;
Direct and prosper my intention.
Command thy servant Deities, Love and Fortune
To second my attempts for this great Lady,
Whose Page I lately was; That she , whose board
I might not sit at, I may board abed
And under bring, who bore so high her head.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: It is miraculous that you tell me Sir: he come to woo our Lady Mistress for his wife?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: It is a frenzy he is possessed with, and will not be cured but by some violent remedy. And you shall favour me so much to make me a spectator of the Scene. But is she (say you) already accessible for Suitors? I thought she would have stood so stiffly on her Widow vow, that she would not endure the sight of a Suitor.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Faith Sir, Penelope could not bar her gates against her wooers, but she will still be Mistress of herself . It is as you know, a certain Itch in female blood, they love to be sued to: but she will hearken to no Suitors.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: But by your leave Lycus, Penelope is not so wise as her husband Ulysses, for he fearing the jaws of the Siren, stopped his ears with wax against her voice. They that fear the Adders sting, will not come near her hissing. Is any Suitor with her now?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: A Spartan Lord, dating himself our great Viceroys Kinsman, and two or three other of his Country Lords, as spots in his train. He comes armed with his Altitudes letters in grace of his person, with promise to make her a Duchess if she embrace the match. This is no mean attraction to her high thoughts; but yet she disdains him.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And how then shall my brother presume of acceptance? yet I hold it much more under her contentment, to marry such a Nasty braggart, than under her honour to wed my brother: A Gentleman (though I say it) more honourably descended than that Lord: who perhaps, for all his Ancestry would be much troubled to name you the place where his Father was borne.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Nay, I hold no comparison betwixt your brother and him. And the Venerian disease, to which they say, he has been long wedded, shall I hope first rot him, ere she endure the savour of his Sulphurous breath. Well, her Ladyship is at hand; you are best take you to your stand.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Thanks good friend Lycus.

div1.stage: Exit. Enter Argus bareheaded, with whom another Usher Lycus joins, going over the Stage. Hiarbas, and Psorabeus next, Rebus single before Eudora, Laodice, Sthenio bearing her train, lanthe following.

sp.speaker: Peb.
sp.p:
I admire Madam, you cannot love whom the
Viceroy loves.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: And one whose veins swell so with his blood, Madam, as they do in his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Pso.
sp.p: A near and dear Kinsman his Lordship is to his Altitude, the Viceroy; In care of whose good speed here. I know his Altitude hath not slept a sound sleep since his departure.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I thank Venus I have , ever since he came.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: You sleep away your Honour, Madam, if you neglect me.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: Neglect your Lordship? that were a negligence no less than disloyalty.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I much doubt that Sir, It were rather a presumption to take him, being of the blood Viceroyal.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Not at all, being offered Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: But offered ware is not so sweet you know. They are the graces of the Viceroy that woo me, not your Lordships, and I conceive it should be neither Honour nor Pleasure to you, to be taken in for another man's favours.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Taken in Madam? you speak as I had no house to hide my head in.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I have heard so indeed, my Lord, unless it be another man's.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: You have heard untruth then; These Lords can well witness I can want no houses.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: Nor Palaces neither my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pso.
sp.p: Nor Courts neither.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Nor Temples I think neither; I believe we shall have a God of him.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: See the bold fellow; whether will you Sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Away, all honour to you Madam?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: How now base companion?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Base Madam: he is not base that fights as high as your lips.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: And does that beseem my servant?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Your Court-servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: One that waited on my board?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: That was only a preparation to my weight on your bed Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: How darest thou come to me with such a thought?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Come to you Madam? I dare come to you at midnight, and bid defiance to the proudest spirit that haunts these your loved shadows; and would any way make terrible the access of my love to you.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Love me? love my dog.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: I am bound to that by the proverb Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Kennel without with him, intrude not here. What is it thou presumest on?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: On your judgment Madam, to choose a Man, and not a By-but, as these are that come with Titles, and Authority, as they would conquer, or ravish you. But I come to you with the liberal and ingenuous Graces, Love, Youth, and Gentry; which (in no more deformed a person than myself) deserve any Princess.

sp.speaker: Eud.
Thar.
sp.p: In blankets Madam, you must add your sheets, and you must be the Tosser.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Nay then Sir you are as gross as you are saucy.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And all one Sir, for I am neither.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Thou art both.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Thou liest; keep up your smiter Lord Rebus.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: Usest thou thus his Altitudes Cousin?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: The place thou knowest protects thee.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Tie up your valour then till another place turn me loose to you, you are the Lord (I take it) that wooed my great Mistress here with letters from his Altitude; which while she was reading, your Lordship (to entertain time) straddled and scaled your fingers; as you would show what an itching desire you had to get betwixt her sheets.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: Slight, why does your Lordship endure him?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: The place, the place my Lord.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Be you his Attorney Sir.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: What would you do Sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Make thee leap out at window, at which thou camest in: Whoreson bagpipe Lords.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What rudeness is this?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: What tameness is it in you Madam, to stick at the discarding of such a suitor? A lean Lord, dubbed with the lard of others? A diseased Lord too, that opening certain Magic Characters in an unlawful book, upstart as many aches in his bones, as there are ouches in his skin. Send him (Mistress) to the Widow your Tenant; the virtuous Panderess Arsace. I perceive he has crowns in his Purse, that make him proud of a string; let her pluck the Goose therefore, and her maids dress him.

sp.speaker: Pso.
sp.p: Still my Lord suffer him?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: The place Sir, believe it the place.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: O good Lord Rebus; The place is never like to be yours that you need respect it so much.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Thou wrongest the noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Noble Gentleman? A tumour, an imposthume he is Madam; a very hautboys, a bagpipe; in whom there is nothing but wind, and that none of the sweetest neither.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Quit the House of him by the head and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Thanks to your Honour Madam, and my Lord Cousin the Viceroy shall thank you.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: So shall he indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Lyc, Arg.
sp.p: Will you be gone sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Away poor Fellows.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What is he made of? or what Devil sees your childish, and effeminate spirits in him, that thus ye shun him? Free us of thy sight; Be gone, or I protest thy life shall go.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Yet shall my Ghost stay still; and haunt those beauties, and glories, that have rendered it immortal.
sp.l: But since I see your blood runs (for the time)
High, in that contradiction that foreruns
Truest agreements (like the Elements Fighting before they generate;) and that Time
Must be attended most, in things most worth;
I leave your Honour freely; and commend
That life you threaten, when you please, to be
Adventured in your service; so your Honour
Require it likewise.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Do not come again.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: I will come again, believe it, and again.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: If he shall dare to come again, I charge you shut doors upon him.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: You must shut them (Madam)
To all men else then, if it please your Honour,
For if that any enter, he will be one.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I hope, wise Sir, a Guard will keep him out.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Afore Heaven, not a Guard (if it please your Honour.)

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thou liest base Ass; One man enforce a Guard?
I will turn ye all away (by our Isles Goddess)
If he but set a foot within my Gates.

sp.speaker: Lurd.
sp.p: Your Honour shall do well to have him poisoned.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: Or begged of your Cousin the Viceroy.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p:
This braving wooer, hath the success expected; The favour I obtained, made me witness to the sport; And let his Confidence be sure, I will give it him
home. The news by this, is blown through the four quarters of the City. Alas good Confidence: but the happiness is he has a forehead of proof; the stain shall never stick there whatsoever, his reproach be.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What? in discourse?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Hell and the Furies take this vile encounter.
Who would imagine this Saturnine Peacock
Could be so barbarous to use a spirit
Of my direction, with such loved respect?
Fore heaven it cuts my gall; but I will dissemble it.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What? my noble Lord?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well Sir, that may be yet, and means to be.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What means your Lordship then to hang that head that hath been so erected; it knocks Sir at your bosom to come in and hide itself.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Not a jot.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: I hope by this time it needs fear no horns.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well Sir, but yet that blessing runs not always in a blood.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What blanketed? O the Gods! spurned out by Grooms like a base Bisogno? thrust out by the head and shoulders?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: You do well Sir to take your pleasure of me, (I may turn tables with you ere long.)

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What has thy wits fine engine taken cold? art stuffed in the head? canst answer nothing?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Truth is, I took my entertainment the better that it was no better.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Now the Gods forbid that this opinion should run in a blood.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Have not you heard this principle, All things by strife engender.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Dogs and Cats do.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And men and women too.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Well Brother, in earnest, you have now set your confidence to school, from whence I hope it has brought home such a lesson as will instruct his master never after to begin such attempts as end in laughter.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: What Sir, you lesson my Confidence still; I pray heavens your confidence have not more shallow ground (for that I know) than mine you reprehend so.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: My confidence? in what?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Maybe you trust too much.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: In human frailty.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Why brother know you aught that may impeach my confidence, as this success may yours? hath your observation discovered any such frailty in my wife (for that is your aim I know) then let me know it.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Good, good. Nay Brother, I write no books of Observations, let your confidence bear out itself, as mine shall me.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: That is scarce a Brothers speech. If there be aught wherein your Brothers good might any way be questioned can you conceal it from his bosom?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: So, so. Nay my saying was but general. I glanced at no particular.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p:
Then must I press you further. You spake (as to
yourself, but yet I overheard) as if you knew some disposition of weakness where I most had fixed my trust. I challenge you to let me know what it was.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Brother? are you wise?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Be ignorant. Did you never hear of Actaeon?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
Curiosity was his death. He could not be content to adore Diana in her Temple, but he must needs dog her to her retired pleasures, and see her in her nakedness. Do you enjoy the sole privilege of your wives bed? have you no pretty Paris for your Page? No mystical Adonis to
front you there?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: I think none: I know not.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Know not still Brother. Ignorance and credulity are your sole means to obtain that blessing. You see your greatest Clerks, your wisest Politicians, are not that way fortunate, your learned Lawyers would lose a dozen poor men's causes to gain a lease on it, but for a Term. Your Physician is jealous of his. Your Sages in general, by seeing too much oversee that happiness. Only your blockheadly Tradesman; your honest meaning Citizen; your not-headed Country Gentleman; your unapprehending Stinkard is blessed with the sole prerogative of his Wives chamber. For which he is yet beholding, not to his stars, but to his ignorance. For if he be wise, Brother, I must tell you the case alters.
How do you relish these things Brother?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Passing ill.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: So do sick men solid meats: hark you brother, are you not jealous?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: No: do you know cause to make me?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Hold you there; did your wife never spice your broth with a dram of sublimate? hath she not yielded up the Fort of her Honour to a staring Soldado? and (taking courage from her guilt) played open bankrupt of all shame, and run the Country with him? Then bless your Stars, bow your knees to Juno. Look where she appears.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: We have sought you long Sir, there is a Messenger within, hath brought you letters from the Court, and desires your speech.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: I can discover nothing in her looks. Go, I will not be long.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Sir, it is of weight the bearer says: and besides, much hastens his departure. Honourable Brother! cry mercy! what, in a Conquerors style? but come and overcome?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A fresh course.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Alas you see of how sleight metal Widows vows are made.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And that shall you prove too ere long.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Yet for the honour of our sex, boast not abroad this your easy conquest; another might perhaps have staid longer below stairs, but upon your confidence, that surprised her love .

sp.speaker: Hylus
sp.p: My uncle hath instructed me how to accost an honourable Lady; to win her, not by suite, but by surprise.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: The Whelp and all.

sp.speaker: Hylus
sp.p: Good Uncle let not your near Honours change your manners, be not forgetful of your promise to me , touching your Ladies daughter Laodice. My fancy runs so upon it , that I dream every night of her.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A good chicken, go thy ways, thou hast done well; eat bread with thy meat.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Come Sir, will you in?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: I will not stir a foot without you. I cannot satisfy the messengers impatience.
Will you not resolve me brother?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Of what?
sp.stage: Lysander stamps and goes out vexed with Cynth. Hyl. Ero.
sp.p:
So, there is veny for veny, I have given it him in the place speeding for all his confidence. Well out of this perhaps there may be moulded matter of more mirth, than my baffling. It shall go hard but I will make my
constant sister act as famous a Scene as Virgil did his Mistress; who caused all the Fire in Rome to fail so; that none could light a torch but at her nose. Now forth: At this house dwells a virtuous Dame, sometimes of worthy Fame, now like a decayed Merchant turned Broker, and retails refuse commodities for unthrifty Gallants. Her wit I must employ upon this business to prepare my next encounter, but in such a fashion as shall make all split. Ho? Madam Arsace? pray heaven the Oyster wives have not brought the news of my wooing hither amongst their stale Pilchards.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: What? my Lord of the Palace?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Look you.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Why, this was done like a beaten Soldier.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Hark, I must speak with you. I have a share for you in this rich adventure. You must be the Ass charged with Crowns to make way to the Fort, and I the Conqueror to follow, and seize it. Seest thou this jewel?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Is it come to that? why Tomasin.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Did not one of the Countesses Serving-men tell us that this Gentleman was sped?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: That he did, and how her honour graced and entertained him in very familiar manner.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: And brought him downstairs herself .

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Aye forsooth, and commanded her men to bear him out of doors.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Slight, pelted with rotten eggs?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Nay more, that he had already possessed her sheets.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No indeed Mistress, it was her blankets.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Out you young hedge-sparrow, learn to tread afore you be fledge.
Well have you done now Lady.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: O my sweet killbuck.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: You now, in your shallow pate, think this a disgrace to me , such a disgrace as is a battered helmet on a soldiers head, it doubles his resolution. Say, shall I use thee?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Use me?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: O holy reformation! how art thou fallen down from the upper bodies of the Church to the skirts of the City! honesty is stripped out of his true substance into verbal nicety. Common sinners startle at common terms, and they that by whole mountains swallow down the deeds of darkness; A poor mote of a familiar word, makes them turn up the white of the eye. Thou art the Ladies Tenant.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: For term Sir.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A good induction, be successful for me, make me Lord of the Palace, and thou shalt hold thy Tenement to thee and thine ears forever, in free smockage, as of the manner of Panderage, provided always.

sp.speaker: Arsa.
sp.p: Nay if you take me unprovided.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Provided I say, that thou makest thy repair to her presently with a plot I will instruct thee in; and for thy surer access to her greatness, thou shalt present her, as from thyself with this jewel.

sp.speaker: Arsa.
sp.p: So her old grudge, stand not betwixt her and me.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Fear not that.
sp.l: Presents are present cures for female grudges,
Make bad, seem good; alter the case with Judges.

div1.stage: Actus Secundi. Scoena Prima. Lysander, Tharsalio.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: So now we are ourselves. Brother, that ill relished speech you let slip from your tongue, hath taken so deep hold of my thoughts, that they will never give me rest, till I be resolved what it was you said, you know, touching my wife.

sp.speaker: Thars.
sp.p: Tush: I am weary of this subject, I said not so.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: By truth itself you did: I overheard you. Come, it shall nothing move me, whatsoever, it be; pray thee unfold briefly what you know.

sp.speaker: Thars.
sp.p: Why briefly Brother. I know my sister to be the wonder of the Earth; and the Envy of the Heavens, Virtuous, Loyal, and what not. Briefly, I know she hath vowed, that till death and after death, she will hold inviolate her bonds to you, and that her black shall take no other hew; all which I firmly believe. In brief Brother, I know her to be a woman. But you know brother, I have other irons on shall anvil.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: You shall not leave me so unsatisfied; tell me what it is you know.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Why Brother; if you be sure of your wives loyalty for term of life: why should you be curious to search the Almanacs for after-times: whether some wandering Aeneas should enjoy your reversion; or whether your true Turtle would sit mourning on a withered branch, till Atropos cut her throat: Beware of curiosity, for who can resolve you? you will say perhaps her vow.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Perhaps I shall.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
Tush, herself knows not what she shall do,
when she is transformed into a Widow. You are now a sober and staid Gentleman. But if Diana for your curiosity should translate you into a monkey; do you know what gambolds you should play? your only way to be resolved is to die and make trial of her.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: A dear experiment, then I must rise again to be resolved.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: You shall not need. I can send you speedier advertisement of her constancy, by the next Rippier that rides that way with Mackerel. And so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: All the Furies in hell attend thee; has given me a
Bone to tire on with a pestilence; slight know?
What can he know? what can his eye observe
More than mine own, or the most piercing sight
That ever viewed her? by this light I think
Her privatest thought may dare the eye of heaven,
And challenge the envious world to witness it.
I know him for a wild corrupted youth,
Whom profane Ruffians, Squires to Bawds, and Strumpets,
Drunkards, spewed out of Taverns, into the sinks
Of Tap-houses, and Stews, Revolts from manhood;
Debauched perdu's, have by their companies
Turned Devil like themselves, and stuffed his soul
With damned opinions, and unhallowed thoughts
Of womanhood, of all humanity,
Nay Deity itself.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Welcome friend Lycus.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Have you met with your capricious brother?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: He parted hence but now.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: And has he yet resolved you of that point you brake with me about?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yes, he bids me die for further trial of her constancy.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p:
That were a strange Physic for a jealous patient; to cure his thirst with a draught of poison. Faith Sir, discharge your thoughts on it; think it was but a Buzz devised
by him to set your brains awork, and divert your eye from his disgrace. The world hath written your wife in highest lines of honoured Fame: her virtues so admired in this Isle , as the report thereof sounds in foreign ears; and strangers oft arriving here, (as some rare sight) desire to view her presence, thereby to compare the Picture with the original. Nor think he can turn so far rebel to his blood,
sp.l: Or to the Truth itself to misconceive
Her spotless love and loyalty; perhaps
Oft having heard you hold her faith so sacred
As you being dead, no man might stir a spark
Of virtuous love , in way of second bonds;
As if you at your death should carry with you
Both branch and root of all affection.
It may be, in that point he is an Infidel,
And thinks your confidence may overween.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: So think not I.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Nor I: if ever any made it good.
I am resolved of all, she will prove no changeling.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well, I must yet be further satisfied;
And vent this humour by some strain of wit,
Somewhat I will do; but what, I know not yet.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Passion of Virginity, Ianthe, how shall we quit ourselves of this Panderess, that is so importunate to speak with us? Is she known to be a Panderess?

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Aye, as well as we are known to be waiting women.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: A shrew take your comparison.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Let us call out Argus that bold Ass that never weighs what he does or says; but walks and talks like one in a sleep; to relate her attendance to my Lady, and present her.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Who? if it please your Honour? None so fit to set on any dangerous exploit.
Ho? Argus?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: What is the matter Wenches?

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: You must tell my Lady here is a Gentlewoman called Arsace, her Honours Tenant, attends her, to impart important business to her.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: I will presently.

sp.speaker: Iant.
sp.p: Well, she has a welcome present, to bear out her unwelcome presence: and I never knew but a good gift would welcome a bad person to the purest. Arsace?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Aye mistress.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Give me your Present, I will do all I can, to make way both for it and yourself.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: You shall bind me to your service Lady.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Stand unseen.

div1.stage: Enter Lyc. Eudora, Laodice, Reb, Hiar Psor. coming after, Argus coming to Eudora.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Here is a Gentlewoman (if it Please your Honour) one of your Tenants Desires access to you.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What Tenant? what is her name?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Arsace, she says Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Arsace? what the Bawd?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: The Bawd Madam?
that is without my privity.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Out Ass, knowest not thou the Panderess Arsace?

sp.speaker: Sth.
sp.p: She presents your Honour with this Jewel?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: This jewel? how came she by such a jewel? She has had great Customers.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: She had need Madam, she sits at a great Rent.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Alas for your great Rent: I will keep her jewel, and keep you her out, ye were best: speak to me for a Panderess?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Go to; Let us alone. Arsace?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Aye Lady.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: You must pardon us, we cannot obtain your access.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Mistress Sthenio, tell her Honour, if I get not access To her, and that instantly she is undone.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: This is something of importance. Madam, she swears your Honour is undone if she speak not with you instantly.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Undone?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Pray her for her Honours sake to give me instant access to her.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: She makes her business your Honour Madam, and entreats for the good of that, her instant speech with you.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: How comes my Honour in question? Bring her to me .

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Our Cypriane Goddess save your good Honour.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Stand you off I pray: How dare you Mistress importune access to me thus, considering the last warning I gave for your absence?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Because, Madam, I have been moved by your Honours last most chaste admonition, to leave the offensive life I led before.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I? have you left it then?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Aye, I assure your Honour, unless it be for the pleasure of two or three poor Ladies, that have prodigal Knights to their husbands.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Out on thee Impudent.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Alas Madam, we would all be glad to live in our callings.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Is this the reformed life thou talkest on?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: I beseech your good Honour mistake me not, I boast of nothing but my charity, that is the worst.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: You get these jewels with charity, no doubt. But what is the point in which my Honour stands endangered I pray?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: In care of that Madam, I have presumed to offend your chaste eyes with my presence. Hearing it reported for truth and generally, that your Honour will take to husband a young Gentleman of this City called Tharsalio.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I take him to husband?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: If your Honour does, you are utterly undone, for he is the most incontinent, and insatiate Man of Women that ever VENUS blessed with ability to please them.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Let him be the Devil; I abhor his thought, and could I be informed particularly of any of these slanderers of mine Honour, he should as dearly dare it, as anything wherein his life were endangered.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Madam, the report of it is so strongly confident, that I fear the strong destiny of marriage is at work in it. But if it be Madam: Let your Honours known virtue resist and defy it for him: for not a hundred will serve his one turn. I protest to your Honour, When (VENUS pardon me ) I winked at my unmaidenly exercise. I have known nine in a Night made mad with his love .

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What tellest thou me of his love ? I tell thee I abhor him; and destiny must have another mold for my thoughts, than Nature or mine Honour, and a Witchcraft above both, to transform me to another shape, as soon as to another conceit of him.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Then is your good Honour just as I pray for you, and good Madam, even for your virtues sake, and comfort of all your Dignities, and Possessions; fix your whole Womanhood against him. He will so enchant you, as never man did woman: Nay a Goddess (say his light housewives) is not worthy of his sweetness.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Go to, be gone.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Dear Madam, your Honours most perfect admonitions have brought me to such a hate of these imperfections, that I could not but attend you with my duty, and urge his unreasonable manhood to the fill.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Manhood, quoth you?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Nay Beastlihood, I might say, indeed Madam, but for saving your Honour; Nine in a night said I?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Go to, no more.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: No more Madam? that is enough one would think.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Well be gone I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Alas Madam, your Honour is the chief of our City, and to whom shall I complain of these inchastities, (being your Ladyships reformed Tenant) but to you that are chastest?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I pray thee go thy ways, and let me see this reformation you pretend continued.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: I humbly thank your good Honour, that was first cause of it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Here is a complaint as strange as my Suitor.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: I beseech your good Honour think upon him, make him an example.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Yet again?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: All my duty to your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: These sorts of licentious persons, when they are once reclaimed, are most vehement against licence. But it is the course of the world to dispraise faults and use them; that so we may use them the safer. What might a wise Widow resolve upon this point now? Contentment is the end of all worldly beings: Beshrew her; would she had spared her news.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: See if she take not a contrary way to free herself of us.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: You must complain to his Altitude.

sp.speaker: Psor.
sp.p: All this for trial is; you must endure That will have wives, nought else, with them is sure.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Hast thou been admitted then?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p:
Admitted? Aye, into her heart, I will able it; never was man so praised with a dispraise; nor so spoken for in being railed on. I will give you my word; I have set her heart upon as tickle a pin as the needle of a Dial; that will never
let it rest, till it be in the right position.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Why dost thou imagine this?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Because I saw Cupid shoot in my words, and open his wounds in her looks. Her blood went and came of errands betwixt her face and her heart; and these changes I can tell you are shrewd telltales.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Thou speakest like a Doctrisse in thy faculty; but howsoever, for all this foil, I will retrieve the game once again, he is a shallow gamester that for one displeasing cast gives up so fair a game for lost.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: Well, it was a villainous invention of thine, and had a swift operation, it took like sulphur. And yet this virtuous Countess hath to my ear spun out many a tedious lecture of pure sisters thread against concupiscence. But ever with such an affected zeal, as my mind gave me, she had a kind of secret titillation to grace my poor house sometimes; but that she feared a spice of the Sciatica, which as you know ever runs in the blood.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And as you know, soaks into the bones. But to say truth, these angry heats that break out at the lips of these straight laced Ladies, are but as symptoms of a lustful fever that boils within them. For wherefore rage wives at their husbands so, when they fly out, for zeal against the sin?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.p: No, but because they did not purge that sin.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Thou art a notable Siren, and I swear to thee, if I prosper, not only to give thee thy manor house gratis, but to marry thee to some one Knight or other, and bury thy trade in thy Ladyship: Go be gone.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: What news Lycus? where is the Lady?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Retired into her Orchard.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A pregnant badge of love , she is melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: It is with the sight of her Spartan wooer. But howsoever it is with her, you have practised strangely upon your Brother.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: You had almost lifted his wit off the hinges. That spark jealousy falling into his dry melancholy brains, had well near set the whole house on fire.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: No matter, let it work; I did but pay him in his own coin; 'sfoot he plied me with such a volley of unseasoned scoffs, as would have made Patience itself turn Ruffian, attiring itself in wounds and blood: but is his humour better qualified then?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p:
Yes, but with a medicine ten parts more dangerous than the sickness: how know you strange his dotage ever was on his wife; taking special glory to have her love and
loyalty to him so renowned abroad. To whom she oftentimes hath vowed constancy after life, till her own death had brought forsooth, her widow troth to bed. This he joyed in strangely, and was therein of infallible belief, till your surmise began to shake it; which hath loosed it so, as now there is nought can settle it, but a trial, which he is
resolved upon .

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: As how man? as how?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: He is resolved to follow your advice, to die, and make trial of her stableness, and you must lend your hand to it.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: What to cut his throat?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: To forge a rumour of his death, to uphold it by circumstance, maintain a public face of mourning, and all things appertaining.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Aye, but the means man: what time? what probability.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Nay, I think he has not licked his Whelp into full shape yet, but you shall shortly hear of it.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And when shall this strange conception see light?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Forthwith: there is nothing stays him, but some odd business of import, which he must wind up ; least perhaps his absence by occasion of his intended trial be prolonged above his aims.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Thanks for this news in faith. This may perhaps prove happy to my Nephew. Truth is I love my sister well and must acknowledge her more than ordinary virtues. But she hath so possessed my brothers heart with vows, and disavowings, sealed with oaths of second nuptials; as in that confidence, he hath invested her in all his state, the ancient inheritance of our Family: and left my Nephew and the rest to hang upon her pure devotion; so as he dead, and she matching (as I am resolved she will) with some young Prodigal; what must ensue, but her post-issue beggared, and our house already sinking, buried quick in ruin. But this trial may remove it, and since it is come to this; mark but the issue Lycus, for all these solemn vows, if I do not make her prove in the handling as weak as a wafer; say I lost my time in travail. This resolution then has set his wits in joint again, he is quiet.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Yes, and talks of you again in the fairest manner, listens after your speed.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Nay he is passing kind, but I am glad of this trial for all that.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Which he thinks to be a flight beyond your wing.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: But he will change that thought ere long. My Bird you saw even now, sings me good news, and makes hopeful signs to me.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Somewhat can I say too, since your messengers departure, her Ladyship hath been something altered, more pensive than before, and took occasion to question of you, what your addictions were? of what taste your humour was? of what cut you wore your wit, and all this in a kind of disdainful scorn.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Good Calendars Lycus. Well I will pawn this jewel with thee, my next encounter shall quite alter my brothers judgment. Come let us in, he shall commend it for a discreet and honourable attempt.
sp.l: Men's judgments sway on that side fortune leans,
Thy wishes shall assist me:

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: And my means.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: I must confess I was ignorant, what it was to court a Lady till now.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: And I pray you what is it now?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: To court her I perceive, is to woo her with letters from Court, for so this Spartan Lords Court discipline teacheth.

sp.speaker: Sth.
sp.p: His Lordship hath procured a new Packet from his Altitude.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: If he bring no better ware than letters in his packet, I shall greatly doubt of his good speed.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: If his Lordship did but know how gracious his Aspect is to my Lady in this solitary humour.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Well these retired walks of hers are not usual; and bode some alteration in her thoughts. What may be the cause Sthenio.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Nay it would trouble Argus with his hundred eyes to descry the cause.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Venus keep her upright, that she fall not from the state of her honour; my fear is that some of these Serpentine suitors will tempt her from her constant vow of widowhood. If they do, good night to our good days.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: It were a sin to suspect her; I have been witness to so many of her fearful protestations to our late Lord against that course, to her infinite oaths imprinted on his lips, and sealed in his heart with such imprecations to her bed, if ever it should receive a second impression, to her open and often detestations of that incestuous life (as she termed it) of widows marriages, as being but a kind of lawful adultery; like usury permitted by the law, not approved. That to wed a second, was no better than to cuckold the first: That women should entertain wedlock as one body, as one life, beyond which there were no desire, no thought, no repentance from it, no restitution to it. So as if the conscience of her vows should not restrain her, yet the worlds shame to break such a constant resolution, should repress any such motion in her.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Well, for her vows, they are gone to heaven with her husband, they bind not upon earth: And as for Women's resolutions, I must tell you, The Planets, and (as Ptolomie says) the winds have a great stroke in them. Trust not my learning if her late strangeness, and exorbitant solitude, be not hatching some new Monster.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Well applied Argus; Make you husbands Monsters?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: I spoke of no husbands, but you Wenches have the pregnant wits, to turn Monsters into husbands, as you turn husbands into monsters.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Well Ianthe, it were high time we made in, to part our Lady and her Spartan wooer.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: We shall appear to her like the two fortunate Stars in a tempest, to save the shipwreck of her patience.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p:
Aye, and to him too , I believe; For by this time he hath
spent the last dram of his news.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: That is, of his wit.

sp.speaker: Sth.
sp.p: Just good wittols.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: If not, that my Lady be not too deep in her new dumps, we shall hear from his Lordship; what such a Lord said of his wife the first night he embraced her: To what Gentleman such a Count was beholding for his five children. What young Lady, such an old Count should marry; what Revels: what presentiments are towards; and who penned the Pegmas; and so forth: and yet for all this, I know her harsh Suitor hath tired her to the uttermost scruple of her forbearances, and will do more, unless we two, like a pair of Shears, cut asunder the thread of his discourse.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Well then, let us in; But my masters, wait you on your charge at your perils, See that you guard her approach from any more intruders.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Excepting young Tharsalio.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: True, excepting him indeed, for a guard of men is not able to keep him out if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: O Wenches, that is the property of true valour, to promise like Pygmy, and perform like a Giant. If he come, I will be sworn I will do my Ladies commandment upon him.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: What? beat him out?

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: If he should, Tharsalio would not take it ill all at his hands, for he does but his Ladies commandment.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Well, by Hercules he comes not here.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: By Venus but he does: or else she hath heard my Ladies prayers, and sent some gracious spirit in his likeness to fright away that Spartan wooer, that haunts her.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: There stand her Sentinels.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Slight the Ghost appears again.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Save ye my quondam fellows in Arms; save ye; my women.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Your Women Sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: It will be so. What no courtesies? No preparation of grace? observe me I advise you for your own sakes.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: For your own sake, I advise you to pack hence, lest your impudent valour cost you dearer than you think.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What senseless boldness is this Tharsalio?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Well said Clinias, talk to him.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I wonder that notwithstanding the shame of your last entertainment, and threatenings of worse; you would yet presume to trouble this place again.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Come you are a wigeon; Off with your hat Sir, acknowledge: forecast is better than labour. Are you squint eyed? can you not see afore you. A little foresight I can tell you might stead you much as the Stars shine now.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: It is well sir, it is not for nothing your brother is ashamed on you. But Sir, you must know, we are charged to bar your entrance.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: But Whiffler, know you, that who so shall date to execute that charge, I will be his Executioner.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: By Jove, Clinias, methinks, the Gentleman speaks very honourably.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well see this house needs reformation, here is a fellow stands behind now, of a forwarder insight than ye all. What place hast thou?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: What place you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Law you Sir. Here is a fellow to make a Gentleman Usher Sir, I discharge you of the place, and do here invest thee into his room, Make much of thy hair, thy wit will suit it rarely. And for the full possession of thine office; Come, Usher me to thy Lady: and to keep thy hand supple, take this from me.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: No bribes Sir, if it please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Go to, thou dost well; but pocket it for all that; it is no impair to thee: the greatest do it.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Sir, it is your love only that I respect, but since out of your love you please to bestow it upon me, It were want of Courtship in me to refuse it; I will acquaint my Lady with your coming.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: How say by this? have not I made a fit choice, that hath so soon attained the deepest mystery of his profession: Good sooth Wenches, a few curtsies had not been cast upon your new Lord.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: We will believe that, when our Lady has a new Son of your getting.

div1.stage: Enter Argus, Eudora, Rebus, Hiar. Psor.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What is the matter? who is that, you say, is come?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: The bold Gentleman, if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Why thou fleering Ass thou.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: If it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Did not I forbid his approach by all the charge and duty of thy service?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Madam, this fellow only is intelligent; for he truly understood your command according to the style of the Court of Venus; that is, by contraries: when you forbid you bid.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: By heaven I will discharge my house of ye all.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: You shall not need Madam, for I have already cashiered your officious Usher here, and choosed this for his Successor.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: O incredible boldness!

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Madam, I come not to command your love with enforced letters, nor to woo you with tedious stories of my Pedigree, as he who draws the thread of his descent from Ledas Distaff; when it is well known his Grandsire cried Cony skins in Sparta.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Whom mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Sir, I name none, but him who first shall name himself.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: The place Sir, I tell you still; and this Goddesses fair presence, or else my reply should take a far other form upon it .

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: If it should Sir, I would make your Lordship an answer.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Anser is Latin for a Goose, if it please your honour.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Well noted Gander; and what of that?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Nothing, if it please your Honour, but that he said he would make his Lordship an answer.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Thus every fool mocks my poor Suitor. Tell me thou most frontless of all men, didst thou (when thou hadst means to note me best) ever observe so base a temper in me , as to give any glance at stooping to my Vassal?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Your drudge Madam, to do your drudgery.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Or am I now so scant of worthy Suitors, that may advance mine honour; advance my estate; strengthen my alliance (if I list to wed) that I must stoop to make my foot my head.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
No but your side, to keep you warm abed. But Madam vouchsafe me your patience to that points serious answer. Though I confess to get higher place in your graces, I could wish my fortunes more honourable; my person more gracious; my mind more adorned with Noble and Heroical virtues, yet Madam (that you think not your blood disparaged by mixture with mine) deign to know this: howsoever I once, only for your love , disguised
myself in the service of your late Lord and mine, yet my descent is as honourable as the proudest of your Spartan attempters; who by unknown quills or conduits under ground, draws his Pedigree from Lycnrgus his great Toe, to the Viceroys little finger, and from thence to his own elbow, where it will never leave itching.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It is well Sir, presume still of the place.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: 'sfoot Madam, am I the first great personage that hath stooped to disguises for love ? what think you of our Countryman Hercules; that for love put on Omphales Apron, and sate spinning amongst her Wenches, while his Mistress wore his Lions skin and Lamb skinned him, if he did not his business.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Most fitly thou resemblest thyself to that violent Atlas, that claimed all other men's possessions as his own by his mere valour. For what less hast thou done? Come into my house, beat away these Honourable persons?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: That I will Madam. Hence ye Sparta Velvet.

sp.speaker: Psor.
sp.p: Hold, she did not mean so.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Away I say, or leave your lives I protest here.

sp.speaker: Hiar.
sp.p: Well Sir, his Altitude shall know you.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I will do your errand Sir.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
Do good Cousin Altitude; and beg the reversion of the next Lady: for Dido has betrothed her love to me. By
this fair hand Madam, a fair riddance of this Caledonian Bore.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: O most prodigious audaciousness!

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: True Madam; O fie upon them, they are intolerable. And I cannot but admire your singular virtue of patience, not common in your sex; and must therefore carry with it some rare endowment of other Masculine and Heroical virtues. To hear a rude Spartan court so ingenuous a Lady, with dull news from Athens, or the Viceroys court; how many dogs were spoiled at the last Bull-baiting; what Ladies dubbed their husbands Knights, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: But hast thou no shame? No sense of what disdain I showed thee in my last entertainment? chasing thee from my presence, and charging thy duty, not to attempt the like intrusion for thy life; and darest thou yet approach me in this unmannerly manner? No question this desperate boldness cannot choose but go accompanied with other infinite rudenesses.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Good Madam, give not the Child an unfit name, term it not boldness, which the Sages call true confidence, founded on the most infallible Rock of a woman's constancy.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: If shame cannot restrain thee, tell me yet if any brainless fool would have tempted the danger attending thy approach.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: No Madam, that proves I am no Fool: Then had I been here a Fool, and a base low spirited Spartan, if for a Ladies frown, or a Lords threats, or for a Guard of Grooms, I should have shrunk in the wetting, and suffered such a delicious flower to perish in the stalk, or to be savagely plucked by a profane finger. No Madam: First let me be made a Subject for disgrace; let your remorseless Guard seize on my despised body, bind me hand and foot, and hurl me into your Ladyships bed.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: O Gods: I protest thou dost more and more make me admire thee.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Madam, ignorance is the mother of admiration: know me better, and you will admire me less.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What wouldst thou have me know? what seeks thy coming? why dost thou haunt me thus?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Only Madam, that the AEtna of my sighs, and Nilus of my tears, poured forth in your presence, might witness to your Honour the hot and moist affection of my heart, and work me some measure of favour, from your sweet tongue, or your sweeter lips, or what else your good Ladyship shall esteem more conducible, to your divine contentment.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Pen and Inkhorn I thank thee. This you learned when you were a Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Madam, I am still the same creature; and I will so tie my whole fortunes to that style, as were it my happiness (as I know it will be) to mount into my Lords succession. yet vow I never to assume other Title, or State, than your servants: Not approaching your board, but bidden: Not pressing to your bed, but your pleasure shall be first known if you will command me any service.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Thy vows are as vain as a Ruffians oaths; as common as the air; and as cheap as the dust. How many of the light housewives, thy Muses, hath thy love promised this service besides, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Compare shadows to bodies, Madam; Pictures to the life; and such are they to you, in my valuation.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I see words will never free me of thy boldness, and will therefore now use blows; and those of the mortalest enforcement. Let it suffice Sir, that all this time, and to this place, you enjoy your safety; keep back: No one foot follow me further; for I protest to thee, the next threshold past, let us pass a prepared Ambush to thy latest breath.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: This for your Ambush,
Dare my love with death?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Slight; follow if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Not I by this light.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I hope Gentlewomen you will.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.p: Not we Sir, we are no parters of frays.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Faith nor I will be any breaker of customs.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Would any heart of Adamant, for satisfaction of an ungrounded humour, rack a poor Ladies innocency as you intend to do. It was a strange curiosity in that Emperor, that ripped his Mothers womb to see the place he lay in.

sp.speaker: Lys.
Cynth.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: I pray thee wife show but thyself a woman; and be silent: question no more the reason of my journey, which our great Viceroys charge urged in this letter doth enforce me to.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Let me but see that letter, there is something in this presaging blood of mine, tells me this sudden journey can portend no good, resolve me sweet, have not I given you cause of discontent, by some misprision, or want of fit observance, let me know that I may wreak myself upon myself.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: Come wife, our love is now grown old and staid,
And must not wanton it in tricks of Court,
Nor interchanged delights of melting lovers;
Hanging on sleeves, sighing, loath to depart;
These toys are past with us; our true loves substance
Hath worn out all the show, let it suffice,
I hold thee dear: and think some cause of weight
With no excuse to be dispensed with all,
Compels me from thy most desired embraces;
I stay but for my Brother, came he not in last night.

sp.speaker: Hylus
sp.p: For certain no sir, which gave us cause of wonder, what accident kept him abroad.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Pray heaven it prove not some wild resolution, bred in him by his second repulse from the Countess.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Trust me I something fear it, this insatiate spirit of aspiring, being so dangerous and fatal; desire mounted on the wings of it, descends not but headlong.

sp.speaker: Hylus
sp.p: Sir, sir, here is my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: What wrapped in careless cloak, face hid in hat unbanded, these are the ditches brother, in which outraging colts plunge both themselves and their riders.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well, we must get out as well as we may, if not, there is the making of a grave saved.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: That is desperately spoken brother, had it not been happier the colt had been better broken, and his rider not fallen in.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: True sister, but we must ride colts before we can break them, you know.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: This is your blind Goddess Confidence.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
Alas brother, our house is decayed, and my honest ambition to restore it, I hope be pardonable. My comfort is: the Poet that pens the story will write over my head magnis
tamen excidit ausis; which in our native Idiom, let us you know, His mind was high, though Fortune was his Foe.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: A good resolve brother, to out-jest disgrace: come I had been on my journey but for some private speech with you; let us in.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Good brother stay a little, help out this ragged colt out of the ditch.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: How now.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Now I confess my oversight, this have I purchased by my confidence.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: I like you brother, it is the true Garb you know,
What wants in real worth supply in show.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: In show? alas it was even the thing itself,
I oped my counting house, and took away
These simple fragments of my treasury,
Husband my Countess cried take more, more yet,
Yet, I in haste, to pay in part my debt,
And prove myself a husband of her store,
Kissed and came off; and this time took no more.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: But good brother.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Then were our honoured spousal rites performed,
We made all short, and sweet, and close, and sure.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: He is wrapped.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Then did my Ushers, and chief Servants stoop,
Then made my women curtsies, and envied
Their Ladies fortune: I was magnified.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Let him alone, this spirit will soon vanish.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Brother and sister as I love you, and am true servant to Venus, all the premises are serious and true, and the conclusion is: the great Countess is mine, the Palace is at your service, to which I invite you all to solemnise my honoured nuptials.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Can this be credited!

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Good brother do not you envy my fortunate achievement.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Nay I ever said, the attempt was commendable,

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: If the issue were successful.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A good state conclusion, happy events make good the worst attempts. Here are your widow vows sister; thus are ye all in your pure naturals; certain moral disguises of coyness, which the ignorant call modesty, yet borrow of art to cover your busk points; which a blunt and resolute encounter, taken under a fortunate aspect, easily disarms you of; and then alas what are you? poor naked sinners, God wot: weak paper walls thrust down with a finger; this is the way of it, boil their appetites to a full height of lust; and then take them down in the nick.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Is there probability in this; that a Lady so great, so virtuous, standing on so high terms of honour, should so soon stoop?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: You would not wonder sister, if you knew the lure she stooped at: greatness? think you that can curb affection; no, it whets it more; they have the full stream of blood, to bear them: the sweet gale of their sublimed spirits to drive them: the calm of ease to prepare them: the sunshine of fortune to allure them: Greatness to waft them safe through all Rocks of infamy: when youth, wit, and person come aboard once, tell me sister, can you choose but hoist sail, and put forward to the maine?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: But let me wonder at this frailty yet; would she in so short time wear out his memory, so soon wipe from her eyes, nay, from her heart, whom I myself, and this whole Isle besides, still remember with grief, the impression of his loss taking worthily such root in us; how think you Wife?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.l: I am ashamed of it, and abhor to think,
So great and vowed a pattern of our sex,
Should take into her thoughts, nay to her bed,
(O stain to womanhood) a second love .

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: In so short time.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: In any time.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: No wife.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: By Juno no; sooner a loathsome Toad.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: High words believe me, and I think she will keep them; next turn is yours Nephew; you shall now marry my noblest Lady daughter; the first marriage in Paphos; next my nuptials shall be yours; these are strange occurrents brother, but pretty and pathetical: if you see me in my chair of Honour; and my Countess in mine arms; you will then believe, I hope, I am Lord of the Palace, then shall you try my great Ladies entertainment; see your hands freed of me , and mine taking you to advancement.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Well, all this rids not my business; wife you shall be there to partake the unexpected honour of our House. Lycus, and I will make it our recreation by the way, to think of your Revels and Nuptial sports; Brother my stay hath been for you; Wife pray thee be gone, and soon prepare for the solemnity, a Month returns me .

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Heavens guide your journey.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Farewell Nephew; prosper in virility, but do you hear; keep your hand from your voice, I have a part for you in our Hymeneal show.

sp.speaker: Hylus
sp.p: You speak too late for my voice, but I will discharge the part.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Occurrents call ye them; foul shame confound them all; that impregnable Fort of chastity and loyalty, that amazement of the world; O ye Deities could nothing restrain her? I took her spirit to be too haughty for such a depression.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: But who commonly more short-heeled; than they that are high in the in-step.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Methinks yet shame should have controlled so sudden an appetite.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Tush, shame doth extinguish lust as oil doth fire,
The blood once her, shame doth inflame the more,
What they before, by art dissembled most
They act more freely; shame once found is lost;
sp.p: And to say truth Brother; what shame is due to it? or what congruence doth it carry, that a young Lady, Gallant, Vigorous, full of Spirit, and Complexion; her appetite new whetted with Nuptial delights; to be confined to the speculation of a deaths head, or for the loss of a husband, the world affording flesh enough, make the noontide of her years, the sunset of her pleasures.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: And yet there have been such women.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Of the first stamp perhaps, when the metal was purer than in these degenerate days; of later years, much of that coin hath been counterfeit, and besides so cracked and worn with use, that they are grown light, and indeed fit for nothing, but to be turned over in play.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Not all brother.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: My matchless sister only excepted: for she , you know is made of another metal, than that she borrowed of her mother. But do you brother sadly intend the pursuit of this trial?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Irrevocably.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: It is a high project: if it be once raised, the earth is too weak to bear so weighty an accident, it cannot be conjured down again, without an earthquake, therefore believe she will be constant.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: No, I will not.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Then believe she will not be constant.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
Thar.
sp.p: If it must needs be so. But hark you brother; have you no other Capricions in your head to entrap my sister in her frailty, but to prove the firmness of her widow vows after your supposed death.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: None in the world.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Then here is my hand, I will be as close, as my Ladies shoe to her foot that pinches and pleases her, and will bear on with the plot, till the vessel split again.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Forge any death, so you can force belief. Say I was poisoned, drowned.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Hanged.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Anything, so you assist it with like circumstance, I need not instruct you: that must be your employment Lycus.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: But brother you must set in too ; to countenance truth out, a hearse there must be too; It is strange to think how much the eye prevails in such impressions; I have marked a Widow, that just before was seen pleasant enough, follow an empty hearse, and weep devoutly.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: All those things leave to me.

sp.speaker: Lysan.
sp.p: But brother for the bestowing of this hearse in the monument of our Family, and the marshaling of a Funeral.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Leave that to my care, and if I do not do the mourner, as lively as your Heir, and weep as lustily as your Widow, say there is no virtue in Onions; that being done, I will come to visit the distressed widow; apply old ends of comfort to her grief, but the burden of my song shall be to tell her words are but dead comforts; and therefore counsel her to take a living comfort; that might Ferret out the thought of her dead husband, and will come prepared with choice of suitors; either my Spartan Lord for grace at the Viceroys Court, or some great Lawyer that may sodder up her cracked estate, and so forth. But what would you say brother, if you should find her married at your arrival.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: By this hand split her Weasand.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well, forget not your wager, a stately chariot with four brave Horses of the Thracian breed, with all appurtenances. I will prepare the like for you, if you prove Victor; but well remembered, where will you lurk the whiles?

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: Mewed up close, some short days journey hence, Lycus shall know the place, write still how all things pass, brother adieu; all joy attend you.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Will you not stay our nuptial now so near.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: I should be like a man that hears a tale
sp.p: And heeds it not; one absent from himself, my wife shall attend the Countess, and my Son.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Whom you shall here at your return call me father, adieu: Jove be your speed.
My Nuptials done, your Funerals succeed.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: A hall, a hall: who is without there?
sp.stage: Enter two or three with cushions.
sp.p:
Come on, you are proper Grooms, are ye not? Slight I think ye are all Bridegrooms, ye take your pleasures
so. A company of dormice. Their Honours are upon coming, and the room not ready. Rushes and seats instantly.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Now, alas fellow Argus, how thou at cumbered with an office?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Perfume sirrah, the room is dampish.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Nay you may leave that office to the Ladies, they will perfume it sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Cry mercy Sir, here is a whole Chorus of Syluans at hand, cornetting, and tripping on the toe, as the ground they trod on were too hot for their feet. The device is rare; and there is your young Nephew too, he hangs in the clouds Deified with Hymens shape.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Is he perfect in his part? has not his tongue learned of the Syluans to trip on the Toe?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p:
Sir, believe it, he does it preciously for accent and
action, as if he felt the part he played: he ravishes all the young Wenches in the Palace: Pray Venus my young Lady Laodice have not some little prick of Cupid in her, she is so diligent at his rehearsals.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: No force, so my next vows be heard, that if Cupid have pricked her, Hymen my cure her.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: You mean your Nephew Sir that presents Hymen.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Why so, I can speak nothing but thou art within me: fie of this wit of thine, it will be thy destruction. But howsoever you please to understand, Hymen send the boy no worse fortune: And where is my Ladies honour?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: At hand Sir, with your unparagoned sister, please you take your chair of Honour Sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Most serviceable Argus, the Gods reward thy service; for I will not.

div1.stage: Enter Eudora, leading Cynthia, Laodice, Sthenio, Ianthe, Ero, with others following.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Come sister, now we must exchange that name
For stranger Titles, let us dispose ourselves
To entertain these Syluane Revellers.
That come to grace our loved Nuptials,
I fear me we must all turn Nymphs tonight ,
To side those sprightly wood gods in their dances;
sp.p: Can you do it nimbly sister? slight what ail you, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: But your looks, methinks , are cloudy; suiting all the Sunshine of this clear honour to your husbands house.
sp.l: Is there aught here that sorts not with your liking?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Blame her not Mistress, if her looks show care.
Excuse the Merchants sadness that hath made
A doubtful venture of his whole estate;
His livelihood, his hopes, in one poor bottom,
To all encounters of the Sea and storms.
Had you husband that you loved as well,
Would you not take his absent plight as ill?
Cavil at every fancy? Not an object
That could present itself, but it would forge
Some vain objection, that did doubt his safety;
True love is ever full of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Jealous? of what? of every little journey?
Mere fancy then is wanton; and doth cast
At those sleight dangers there, too doting glances;
Misgiving minds ever provoke mischances:
Shines not the Sun in his way bright as here?
Is not the air as good? what hazard doubt you?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: His horse may stumble if it please your Honour;
The rain may wet, the wind may blow on him;
Many shrewd hazards watch poor travellers.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: True, and the shrewdest thou hast reckoned us.
Good sister, these cares fit young married wives.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.l: Wives should be still young in their husbands loves.
Time bears no Scythe should bear down them before him.
Our lives he may cut short, but not our loves.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Sister be wise, and ship not in one Bark,
All your ability : if he miscarry,
Your well tried wisdom should look on it for new.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.l: I wish them happy winds that run that course,
From me it is far; One Temple sealed our troth.
One Tomb, one hour shall end, and shroud us both.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well, you are a Phoenix, there be that your cheer Love, with your husband be, your wisdom here.
sp.l: Hark, our sports challenge it; Sit dearest Mistress.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Take your place worthiest servant.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Serve me heaven.
As I my heavenly Mistress, Sit rare sister.

div1.stage: Music: Hymen descends; and six Syluanes enter beneath, with Torches.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: A hall, a hall: let no more Citizens in there.

sp.speaker: Laod.
sp.l: O, Not my Cousin see; but Hymens self.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.l: He does become it most inflamingly.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Hail honoured Bridegroom, and his Princely bride
With the most famed for virtue, Cynthia;
