And this young Lady, bright Laodice,
One rich hope of this noblest Family.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.l: Hark how he courts: he is enamoured too.

sp.speaker: Laod.
sp.l: O grant it Venus, and be ever honoured.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: In grace and love of you, I Hymen searched
The groves and thickets that embrace this Palace
With this clear-flamed, and good aboding Torch
For summons of these fresh and flowery Syluans,
To this fair presence; with their winding Hays,
Active and Antique dances to delight
Your frolic eyes, and help to celebrate
These noblest nuptials; which great Destiny,
Ordained past custom and all vulgar object
To be the readvancement of a house,
Noble and Princely, and restore this Palace
To that name, that six hundred Summers since
Was in possession of this Bridegrooms Ancestors,
The ancient and most virtue-famed Lysandri.
Syluans! the Courtships you make to your Dryads,
Use to this great Bride, and these other Dames,
And heighten with your sports, my nuptial flames.

sp.speaker: Laod.
sp.l: O would himself descend, and me command.

sp.speaker: Sthe.
sp.l: Dance; and his heart catch in another's hand.

div1.stage: Syluans, take out the Bride and the rest: They dance, after which, and all set in their places. Hymen.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Now, what the Power and my Torches influence
Hath in the blessings of your Nuptial joys
(Great Bride and Bridegroom) you shall amply part
Betwixt your free loves, and forgo it never.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Thanks to great Hymen, and fair Syluanes ever.

div1.stage: Actus Quarti. Scoena Prima. Tharsalio, Lycus, with his Arm in a scarf, a nightcap on his head.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: I hope Sir by this time.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Put on man, by ourselves.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
Thar.
sp.p: Faith fellow Lycus, if my wager were weakly built, this unexpected accident might stagger it. For the truth is, this strain is extraordinary, to follow her husbands body into the Tomb, and there for his company to bury herself quick: it is new and stirring, but for all this, I will not despair of my wager.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Why Sir, can you think such a passion dissembled?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
All is one for that, What I think I think; In the mean time forget not to write to my Brother, how the plot hath succeeded, that the news of his death hath taken; a funeral solemnity performed, his supposed Corse bestowed in the monument of our Family, thou and I horrible mourners: But above all that his intolerable virtuous Widow, for his love ; (and for her love ) Ero her handmaid,
are descended with his Corse into the vault; There wipe their eyes time out of mind, drink nothing but their own tears, and by this time are almost dead with famine. There is a point will sting it (for you say it is true) where left you him?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: At Dipolis Sir, some twenty miles hence.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: He keeps close.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Aye sir, by all means; skulks unknown under the name of a strange Knight.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: That may carry him without descrying, for there is a number of strange Knights abroad. You left him well.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Well Sir, but for this jealous humour that haunts him.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well, this news will absolutely purge that humour. Write all, forget not to describe her passion at thy discovery of his slaughter: did she perform it well for her husbands wager?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Perform it, call you it? you may jest; men hunt Hares to death for their sports, but the poor beasts die in earnest: you wager of her passions for your pleasure, but she takes little pleasure in those earnest passions. I never saw such an ecstasy of sorrow, since I knew the name of sorrow. Her hands flew up to her head like Furies, hid all her beauties in her dishevelled hair, and wept as she would turn fountain. I would you and her husband had been behind the Arras but to have heard her. I assure you Sir, I was so transported with the spectacle, that in despite of my discretion, I was forced to turn woman, and bear a part with her. Humanity broke loose from my heart, and streamed through mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: In prose, thou weptest. So have I seen many a moist Auditor do at a play; when the story was but a mere fiction: And didst act the Nuntius well, would I had heard it: couldst thou dress thy looks in a mournful habit?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Not without preparation Sir; no more than my speech, it was a plain acting of an interlude to me, to pronounce the part.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: As how for heavens sake?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Phoebus addressed his chariot towards the West
To change his wearied Coursers, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Nay on, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Lysander and myself beguiled the way
With interchanged discourse, but our chief Theme,
Was of your dearest self, his honoured wife;
Your love , your virtue, wondrous constancy.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Then was her Cue to whimper; on.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: When suddenly appeared as far as sight
A troop of horse, armed as we might discern,
With Javelins, Spears, and such accoutrements.
He doubted nought (As Innocency ever
Is free from doubting ill.)

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: There dropped a tear.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: My mind misgave me.
They might be mountaineers. At their approach
They used no other language but their weapons,
To tell us what they were;
Lysander drew, And bore himself Achilles-like in fight,
And as a Mower sweeps off the heads of Bents,
So did Lysanders sword shave off the points
Of their assaulting lances.
His horse at last, sore hurt, fell under him;
I seeing I could not rescue, used my spurs
To fly away.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: What from thy friend?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Aye in a good quarrel, why not?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Good; I am answered.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: A lance pursued me, brought me back again;
And with these wounds left me to accompany
Dying Lysander: Then they rifled us,
And left us.
They gone; my breath not yet gone, gan to strive
And revive sense: I with my feeble joints
Crawled to Lysander, stirred him, and withal
He gasped; cried Cynthia! and breathed no more.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: O then she howled outright.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Passengers came and in a Chariot brought us
Straight to a Neighbour Town; where I forthwith
Coffined my friend in lead; and so conveyed him
To this sad place.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: It was well; and could not show but strangely.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Well Sir, This tale pronounced with terror, suited with action clothed with such likely circumstance; My wounds in show, her husbands hearse in sight, think what effect it wrought: And if you doubt, let the sad consequence of her retreat to his Tomb, be your woeful instructor.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: For all this, I will not despair of my wager: These
Grieves that sound so loud, prove always light,
True sorrow evermore keeps out of sight.
sp.p: This strain of mourning with Sepulchre, like an overdoing Actor, affects grossly, and is indeed so far forced from the life, that it bewrays itself to be altogether artificial.
sp.l: To set open a shop of mourning! It is palpable.
sp.p: Truth, the substance, hunts not after the shadow of popular Fame. Her officious ostentation of sorrow condemns her sincerity. When did ever woman mourn so unmeasurably, but she did dissemble?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: O Gods! a passion thus borne; thus apparelled with tears, sighs, swoonings, and all the badges of true sorrow, to be dissembled! by Venus I am sorry I ever set foot in it. Could she , if she dissembled, thus dally with hunger, be deaf to the barking of her appetite, not having these four days relieved nature with one dram of sustenance.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: For this does she look to be Deified, to have Hymns made of her, nay to her: The Tomb where she is to be no more reputed the ancient monument of our Family the Lysandri; but the new erected Altar of Cynthia: To which all the Paphian widows shall after their husbands Funerals, offer their wet muckenders, for monuments of the danger they have past, as Seamen do their wet garments at Neptune's Temple after a shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p:
Well, I will apprehend you, at your pleasure: I for my part will say; that if her faith be as constant as her love is
hearty, and unaffected, her virtues may justly challenge a Deity to enshrine them.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
Aye, there is another point too. But one of those virtues
is enough at once. All natures are not capable of all gifts. If the brain of the West, were in the heads of the learned; then might parish clerks be common counsel men, and Poets Aldermen's deputies. My sister may turn Niobe for love ; but till Niobe be turned to a Marble, I will not despair but she may prove a woman. Let the trial run on, if she do not outrun it, I will say Poets are no Prophets, Prognosticators are but Mountebanks, and none tell true but wood mongers.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: A sweet Gentleman you are. I marvel what man? what woman? what name? what action doth his tongue glide over, but it leaves a slime upon it . Well, I will presently to Dipolis, where Lysander stays; and will not say but she may prove frail: But this I will say, If she should chance to break, Her tears are true, though women's truths are weak.

div1.stage: Enter Lysander like a Soldier disguised at all parts, a half Pike, gorget, etc. he discovers the Tomb, looks in and wonders, etc.

sp.l: O miracle of nature! women's glory;
Men's shame; and envy of the Deities!
Yet must these matchless creatures be suspected;
Accused; condemned!
Now by the immortal Gods,
They rather merit Altars, Sacrifice,
Than love and courtship.
Yet see the Queen of these lies here interred;
Tearing her hair; and drowned in her tears.
Which Jove should turn to Crystal; and a Mirror
Make of them; wherein men may see and wonder
At women's virtues. Shall she famish then?
Will men (without dissuasions) suffer thus
So bright an Ornament to earth, tombed quick.
In Earths dark bosom: Ho!
Who is in the Tomb there?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Who calls? whence are you?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I am a Soldier of the watch and must enter.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Amongst the dead?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Do the dead speak? ope or I will force it open.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: What violence is this? what seek you here
Where nought but death and her attendants dwell.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What wretched souls are you that thus by night lurk here amongst the dead?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Good Soldier do not stir her,
sp.p: She is weak, and quickly seized with swooning and passions, and with much trouble shall we both recall her fainting spirits.
Five days thus hath she wasted; and not once seasoned her Palate with the taste of meat; her powers of life are spent; and what remains of her famished spirit, serves not to breath but sigh.
She hath exiled her eyes from sleep, or sight, and given them wholly up to ceaseless tears over that ruthful hearse of her dear Spouse, slain by Bantditos, Nobly borne Lysander.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.p: And hopes she with these heavy notes and cries to call him from the dead? in these five days hath she but made him stir a finger or fetch one gasp of that forsaken life she mourns?
sp.l: Come, honoured Mistress; I admire your virtues;
But must reprove this vain excess of moan;
Rouse yourself Lady, and look up from death,
Well said, it is well; stay by my hand and rise.
This Face hath been maintained with better housewifery.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Lady, I am Sentinel,
Set in this hallowed place, to watch and guard
On forfeit of my life, these monuments
From Rape, and spoiled of sacrilegious hands,
And save the bodies, that without you see
Of crucified offenders; that no friends
May bear them hence, to honoured burial.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Thou seemest an honest Soldier; pray thee then
Be as thou seemest; betake thee to thy charge
And leave this place; add not affliction
To the afflicted.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You misname the children.
For what you term affliction now, in you
Is but self humour; voluntary Penance
Imposed upon yourself: and you lament
As did the Satyr once, that ran affrighted
From that horns sound that he himself had winded.
Which humour to abate, my counsel tending your termed affliction,
What I for Physic give, you take for poison.
I tell you honoured Mistress, these ingredients
Are wholesome, though perhaps they seem untoothsome.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: This Soldier sure, is some decayed apothecary.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Dear Ghost be wise, and pity your fair self
Thus, by yourself unnaturally afflicted:
Chide back, heartbreaking groans, clear up those lamps,
Restore them to their first creation:
Windows for light; not sluices made for tears.
Beat not the senseless air with needless cries,
Baneful to life, and bootless to the dead.
This is the Inn, where all Deucalions race
Sooner or later, must take up their lodging;
No privilege can free us from this prison;
No tears, no prayers, can redeem from hence
A captived soul; Make use of what you see:
Let this affrighting spectacle of death
Teach you to nourish life.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Good hear him: this is a rare Soldier.

sp.speaker: Lysan.
sp.p: Say that with abstinence you should unloose the knot of life: Suppose that in this Tomb for your dear Spouse, you should entomb yourself a living Corse; Say that before your hour without due Summons from the Fates, you send your hasty soul to hell: can your dear Spouse take notice of your faith and constancy? Shall your dear Spouse revive to give you thanks?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Idle discourser.

sp.speaker: Lysan.
sp.l: No, your moans are idle.
Go to I say, be counselled; raise yourself:
Enjoy the fruits of life, there is viands for you,
Now, live for a better husband.
No? will you none?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: For love of courtesy, good Mistress, eat,
Do not reject so kind and sweet an offer,
Who knows but this may be some Mercury
Disguised, and sent from Juno to relieve us?
Did ever any lend unwilling ears
To those that came with messages of life?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.l: I pray thee leave thy Rhetoric.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: By my soul; to speak plain truth, I could rather wish to employ my teeth than my tongue, so your example would be my warrant.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.l: Thou hast my warrant.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: Well then, eat my wench,
Let obstinacy starve.
Fall to.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Persuade my Mistress first.

sp.speaker: Lysand.
sp.l: Slight tell me Lady,
Are you resolved to die? If that be so,
Choose not (for shame) a base, and beggars death:
Die not for hunger, like a Spartan Lady;
Fall valiantly upon a sword, or drink
Noble death, expel your grief with poison,
There it is , seize it. ~~~ Tush you dare not die.
Come Wench thou hast not lost a husband;
Thou shalt eat, thou art now within
The place where I command.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I protest sir.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well said; eat, and protest, or I will protest
And do thou eat; thou eattest against thy will,
That is it thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: And under such a protestation
Thou lost thy Maidenhead.
For your own sake good Lady forget this husband,
Come you are now become a happy
Widow, A blessedness that many would be glad of.
That and your husbands Inventory together,
Will raise you up husbands enough.
What think you of me?

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.l: Trifler, pursue this wanton Theme no further;
Lest (which I would be loath) your speech provoke
Uncivil language from me; I must tell you,
One joint of him I lost, was much more worth
Than the racked value of thy entire body.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: O know what joint she means.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well, I have done.
And well done frailty; proface, how likest thou it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Very toothsome Ingredients surely sir,
Want but some liquor to incorporate them.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: There it is , carouse.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I humbly thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Hold pledge me now.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: It is the poison Sir,
That preserves life, I take it.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Do so, take it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Sighing has made me something short-winded.
I will pledge ye at twice.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: It is well done; do me right.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I pray sir, have you been a Apothecary?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Marry have I wench; A woman's Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Have you good Ingredients?
I like your Bottle well. Good Mistress taste it.
Try but the operation, it will fetch up
The Roses in your cheeks again.
Doctor Verolles bottles are not like it;
There is no Guaicum here, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: This will do well anon.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Now fie upon it .
O I have lost my tongue in this same limbo.
The spring ants, spoiled methinks; it goes not off
With the old twang.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well said wench, oil it well; it will make it slide well.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Aristotle says sir, in his Posterionds.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: This wench is learned; And what sales he?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: That when a man dies, the last thing that moves is his heart, in a woman her tongue.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Right; and adds further, that you women are a kind of spinners; if their legs be plucked off, yet still they will wag them; so will you your tongues.
sp.l: With what an easy change does this same weakness
Of women, slip from one extreme to another?
All these attractions take no hold of her;
No not to take refection; It must not be thus.
Well said wench; Tickle that Helicon.
But shall we quit the field with this disgrace
Given to our Oratory? Both not gain
So much ground of her as to make her eat?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Faith the truth is sir; you are no fit Organ
For this business;
It is quite out of your Element:
Let us alone, she will eat I have no fear;
A woman's tongue best fits a woman's ear.
Jove never did employ Mercury,
But Iris for his Messenger to Juno.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Come, let me kiss thee wench; wilt undertake To make thy Mistress eat?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: It shall go hard Sir
But I will make her turn flesh and blood,
And learn to live as other mortals do.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Well said: the morning hastes; next night expect me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: With more provision good Sir.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: And bring more wine.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: What else; shalt have enough:
O Cynthia, heir of her bright purity,
Whose name thou dost inherit; Thou disdainest
(Severed from all concretion) to feed
Upon the base food of gross Elements.
Thou all art soul; All immortality.
Thou fasts for Nectar and Ambrosia,
Which till thou findest, and eattest above the stars,
To all food here thou biddest celestial wars.

div1.stage: Exit. Cynthia, Ero, the Tomb opening.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: So; let us air our dampish spirits, almost stifled in this gross muddy Element.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: How sweet a breath the calmness of the night inspires the air withal?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Well said; Now you are yourself: did not I tell you how sweet an operation the Soldiers bottle had? And if there be such virtue in the bottle; what is there in the Soldier? know, and acknowledge his worth when he comes in any case Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: So Maid.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Gods my patience? did you look forsooth that Juno should have sent you meat from her own Trencher, in reward of your widows tears? you might sit and sigh first till your heartstrings broke, I will able it.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I fear me thy lips have gone so oft to the bottle, that thy tongue strings are come broken home.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Faith the truth is, my tongue hath been so long tied up , that it is covered with rust, and I rub it against my palate as we do suspected coins, to try whether it be currant or no. But now Mistress for an upshot of this bottle; let us have one carouse to the good speed of my old Master, and the good speed of my new.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: So Damsel.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: You must pledge it, here is to it. Do me right I pray.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: You say I must.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Must? what else?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: How excellent ill this humour suites our habit?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Go to Mistress, do not think but you and I shall have good sport with this jest, when we are in private at home. I would to Venus we had some honest shift or other to get off withal; for I will no more on it; I will not turn Saltpetre in this vault for never a man's company living; much less for a woman's. Sure I am the wonder is over, and it was only for that, that I endured this; and so on my conscience did you. Never deny it.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Nay pray thee take it to thee.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Hark I hear some footing near us.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Gods me it is the Soldier Mistress, by Venus if you fall to your late black Santus again, I will discover you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What is here? The maid hath certainly prevailed with her; methinks those clouds that last night covered her looks are now dispersed: I will try this further. Save you Lady.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Honourable Soldier? you are welcome; please you step in sir?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: With all my heart sweet heart; by your patience Lady; why this bears some shape of life yet. Damsel, thou hast performed a service of high reckoning, which cannot perish unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Faith Sir, you are in the way to do it once, if you have the heart to hold on.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Your bottle has poisoned this wench sir.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: A wholesome poison it is Lady, if I may be judge; of which sort here is one better bottle more.
sp.l: Wine is ordained to raise such hearts as sink,
Whom woeful stars distemper; let him drink.
sp.p: I am most glad I have been some mean to this part of your recovery, and will drink to the rest of it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Go to Mistress, pray simper no more; pledge the man of War here.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Come you are too rude.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Good sooth Lady you are honoured in her service; I would have you live, and she would have you live freely; without which life is but death. To live freely is to feast our appetites freely; without which humans are stones; to the satisfaction whereof I drink Lady.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I will pledge you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Said like a Mistress; and the Mistress of yourself; pledge him in love too: I see he loves you; She is silent, she consents sir.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: O happy stars. And now pardon Lady; methinks these are all of a piece.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Nay, if you kiss all of a piece we shall never have done: Well it was well offered, and as well taken.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: If the world should see this.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: The world! should one so rare as yourself, respect the vulgar world?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: The praise I have had, I would continue.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What of the vulgar? Who hates not the vulgar, deserves not love of the virtuous. And to affect praise of that we despite, how ridiculous it is?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Comfortable doctrine Mistress, edify, edify.
sp.l: Methinks even thus it was when Dido
And Aeneas met in the Cave; And hark
Methinks I hear some of the hunters.

div1.stage: She shuts the tomb. Finis Actus Quarti.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: It is such an obstinacy in you Sir,
As never was conceited, to run on
With an opinion against all the world,
And what your eyes may witness; to adventure
The famishment for grief of such a woman
As all men's merits met in any one,
Could not deserve.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: I must confess it Lycus,
We will therefore now prevent it if we may,
And that our curious trial hath not dwelt
Too long on this unnecessary haunt:
Grief, and all want of food; not having wrought
Too mortally on her divine disposure.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: I fear they have , and she is past our cure.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: I must confess with fear and shame as much.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: And that she will not trust in anything
What you persuade her to.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Then thou shalt haste
And call my brother from his secret shroud,
Where he appointed thee to come and tell him
How all things have succeeded.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: This is well.
If (as I say) the ill be not so grown,
That all help is denied her. But I fear
The matchless Dame is famished.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Slight, who is here? A Soldier with my sister? wipe, wipe, see
Kissing by Jove; she , as I lay it is she :

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: What? is she well Sir?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: O no, she is famished;
She is past our comfort, she lies drawing on.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: The Gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Look thou, she is drawing on.
How sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Drawing on? Illustrious witchcrafts.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Lies she not drawing on?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: She draws on fairly.
Our sister Sir? This she ? can this be she ?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: She, she, she, and none but she.
She only Queen of love , and chastity,
O chastity; This women be.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Slight it is prodigious.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: Horse, horse, horse,
Four Chariot Horses of the Thracian breed,
Come, bring me brother. O the happiest evening,
That ever drew her veil before the Sun.
Who is it canst tell?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: The Soldier Sir that watches
The bodies crucified in this hallowed place.
Of which to lose one, it is death to him,
And yet the lustful knave is at his Venery,
While one might steal one.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: What a slave was I
That held not out my winds strength constantly,
That she would prove thus? O incredible?
A poor eight penny Soldier? She that lately
Was at such height of interjection,
Stoop now to such a base conjunction?
By heaven I wonder now I see it in act,
My brain could ever dream of such a thought.
And yet, it is true: Rare, peerless, is it not Lycus?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: I know not what it is; Nor what to say.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: O had I held out (villain that I was,)
My blessed confidence but one minute longer,
I should have been eternized. Gods my fortune,
What an unspeakable sweet sight it is?
O eyes I will sacrifice to your dear sense.
And consecrate a Phane to Confidence.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: But this you must at no hand tell your brother.
It will make him mad:
For he that was before
So scourged but only with bare jealousy.
What would he be, if he should come to know it?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: He would be less mad: for your only way
To clear his jealousy, is to let him know it.
When knowledge comes suspicion vanishes.
The Sunbeams breaking forth swallow the mists.
But as for you Sir Gallant: howsoever
Your banquet seems sweet in your lickerous palate,
It shall be sure to turn gall in your maw.
Thy hand a little Lycus here without.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.l: No booty serve you sir Soldado
But my poor sister? Come, lend me thy shoulder,
I will climb the cross; it will be such a cooler
To my Venerian Gentleman's hot liver,
When he shall find one of his crucified bodies
Stolen down, and he to be forthwith made fast
In place thereof, for the sign
Of the lost Sentinel. Come glorify
Firm Confidence in great Inconstancy.
And this believe (for all proved knowledge swears)
He that believes in error, never errs.

div1.stage: Exeunt. The Tomb opens, Lysander, Cynthia, Ero.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: It is late; I must away.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Not yet sweet love .

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Tempt not my stay, it is dangerous. The law is strict, and not to be dispensed with. If any Sentinel be too late in his watch, or that by his neglect one of the crucified bodies should be stolen from the cross, his life buys it.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: A little stay will not endanger them.
The days proclaimer has not yet given warning.
The Cock yet has not beat his third alarm.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What? shall we ever dwell here amongst the Antipodes? Shall I not enjoy the honour of my fortune in public? sit in Lysanders chair? Reign in his wealth?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Thou shalt, thou shalt; though my love to thee
Hath proved thus sudden and for haste leapt over
The complement of wooing, Yet only for the worlds opinion.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Mark that again.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I must maintain a form in parting hence.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Out upon it , Opinion the blind Goddess of Fools, Foe to the virtuous; and only friend to undeserving persons, contemn it. Thou knowest thou hast done virtuously; thou hast strangely sorrowed for thy husband, followed him to death; further thou couldst not, thou hast buried thyself quick. (O that it were true) spent more tears over his carcase, than would serve a whole City of saddest widows in a plague time; besides sighings, and swoonings, not to be credited.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: True; but those complements might have their time for fashion sake.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Right, Opinion and Fashion. 'sfoot what call you time? thou hast wept these four whole days.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Nay by our lady almost five.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Look you there; near upon five whole days.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Well go and see; Return, we will go home.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Hell be thy home, Huge Monsters damn ye, and your whole creation, O ye Gods; in the height of her mourning in a Tomb, within sight of so many deaths! her husbands believed body in her eye. He dead, a few days before; this mirror of Nuptial chastity; this Votaress of widow constancy: to change her faith; exchange kisses, embraces, with a stranger; and but my shame withstood, to give the utmost earnest of her love , to an eight penny Sentinel: in effect, to prostitute herself upon her husbands Coffin! Lust, impiety, hell, womanhood itself, add if you can one step to this.

div1.stage: Enter Captain with two or three Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: One of the crucified bodies taken down!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And the Sentinel not to be heard off?
No sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Make out; haste, search about for him; does none of you know him? nor his name?
He is but a stranger here of some four days standing; and we never set eye on him, but at setting the watch.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: For whom serves he? you look well to your watch masters.
For Seignior Stratio, and whence he is, it is ignorant to us; we are not correspondent for any, but our own places.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You are eloquent. Abroad I say, let me have him.

This negligence will by the Governor be wholly cast on me, he hereby will suggest to the Viceroy, that the City guards are very coarsely attended. He loves me not I know; because of late I knew him but of mean condition; but now by fortunes injudicious hand, guided by bribing Courtiers, he is raised to this high seat of honour. Nor blushes he, to see himself advanced over the heads of ten times higher worths; but takes it all forsooth, to his merits; and looks (as all upstarts do) for most huge observance. Well, my mind must stoop to his high place, and learn within itself to sever him from that, and to adore Authority the Goddess, however borne by an unworthy beast; and let the Beasts dull apprehension take the honour done to Isis, done to himself. I must sit fast, and be sure to give no hold to these fault-hunting enemies.

div1.stage: Exit. Tomb opens, and Lysander within lies along, Cynthia and Ero.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pray thee disturb me not; put out the lights.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Faith I will take a nap again.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Thou shalt not rest before I be resolved
What happy wind hath driven thee back to harbour?
Was it my love ?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Yet say so (sweet) that with the thought thereof I may enjoy all that I wish in earth.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I am sought for. A crucified body is stolen while I loitered here; and I must die for it,

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Die? All the Gods forbid; O this affright torments me ten parts more than the sad loss of my dear husband.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: (Damnation) I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Yet hear a woman's wit,
Take counsel of Necessity and it.
I have a body here which once I loved
And honoured above all; but that time is past.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: It is, revenge it heaven.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: That shall supply at so extreme a need the vacant Gibbet.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Canero. What? thy husbands body?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: What hurt is it, being dead it save the living?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O heart hold in, check thy rebellious motion.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Vex not thyself dear love , nor use delay.
Tempt not this danger, set thy hands to work.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: I cannot do it; my heart will not permit
My hands to execute a second murther.
The truth is I am he that slew thy husband.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: The Gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: It was this hand that bathed my reeking sword
In his life blood, while he cried out for mercy,
But I remorseless, paunched him, cut his throat,
He with his last breath crying, Cynthia.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: O thou hast told me news that cleaves my heart,
Would I had never seen thee, or heard sooner
This bloody story; yet see, note my truth Yet I must love thee.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Out upon the Monster.
Go, tell the Governor; Let me be brought
To die for that most famous villainy;
Not for this mitching base transgression
Of tenant negligence.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: I cannot do it.
Love must salve any murther: I will be judge
Of thee dear love , and these shall be thy pains
Instead of iron, to suffer these soft chains.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O I am infinitely obliged.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Arise I say, thou saver of my life.
Do not with vain affrighting conscience
Betray a life, that is not thine but mine:
Rise and preserve it.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Ha? thy husbands body?
Hang it up you say, instead of that thatis stolen;
Yet I his murtherer, is that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: It is my Love.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Thy love amazes me,
The point is yet how we shall get it thither,
sp.p: Ha? Tie a halter about his neck, and drag him to the Gallows: shall I my love ?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: So you may do indeed,
Or if your own strength will not serve, we will aid
Our hands to yours, and bear him to the place.
For heavens love come, the night goes off apace.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: All the infernal plagues dwell in thy soul;
I will fetch a crow of iron to break the coffin.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Do love , be speedy.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: As I wish thy damnation.
sp.p: O I could tear myself into Atoms; off with this Antique, the shirt that Hercules wore for his wife, was not more baneful. Is it possible there should be such a latitude in the Sphere of this sex, to entertain such an extension of mischief, and not turn Devil. What is a woman? what are the worst when the best are so past naming? As men like this let them try their wives again. Put women to the test; discover them; paint them, paint them ten parts more than they do themselves, rather than look on them as they are; Their wits are but painted that dislike their painting. Thou foolish thirster after idle secrets, And ill is abroad; look home, and store and choke thee; There sticks an Achelons horn of all, Copy enough.
sp.l: As much as Alizon of streams receives,
Or lofty Ilea shows of shady leaves.
Who is that?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: I wonder Lycus fails me. Nor can I hear what is become of him. He would not certain ride to Dipolis to call my brother back, without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: My brothers voice; what makes he hereabouts so untimely? I will slip him.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Dear friend, let us know you. A friend least looked for but most welcome, and with many a long look expected here. What sir unbooted? have you been long arrived?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Not long, some two hours before night.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well brother, you have the most rare, admirable, unmatchable wife, that ever suffered for the sin of a husband. I cannot blame your confidence indeed now: it is built on such infallible ground; Lycus I think be gone to call you to the rescue of her life; why she ! O incomprehensible!

sp.speaker: Lysan.
sp.p: I have heard all related since my arrival, we will meet tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: What haste brother? But was it related with what untolerable pains, I and my Mistress, her other friends, Matrons and Magistrates, laboured her diversion from that course?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Thar.
Lys.
sp.p: I have heard all.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
But above all; how since that time, her eyes never harboured
wink of slumber, these six days; no nor tasted the least dram of any sustenance.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: How is that assured?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Not a scruple.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Are you sure there came no Soldier to her nor brought her victuals?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Soldier? what Soldier?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why some Soldier of the watch, that attends the executed bodies: well brother I am in haste; tomorrow shall supply this nights defect of conference; Adieu.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A Soldier? of the watch? bring her victuals? Go to brother I have you in the wind; he is unharnessed of all his travailing accoutrements. I came directly from his house, no word of him there; he knows the whole relation; he is passionate: All collections speak he was the Soldier. What should be the riddle of this? that he is stolen hither into a Soldiers disguise? he should have staid at Dipolis to receive news from us. Whether he suspected our relation; or had not patience to expect it, or whether that furious, frantic capricious Devil jealousy hath tossed him hither on his horns, I cannot conjecture. But the case is clear, he is the Soldier. Sister, look to your fame, your chastity is uncovered. Are they here still? here believe it both most woefully weeping over the bottle.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Who is there.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Tharsalio, open.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Alas Sir, it is no boot to vex your sister, and yourself, she is desperate, and will not hear persuasion, she is very weak.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Here is a true-bred chambermaid. Alas, I am sorry for it; I have brought her meat and Candian wine to strengthen her.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: O the very naming of it, will drive her into a swoon; good Sir forbear.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Yet open sweet, that I may bless mine eyes with sight of her fair shrine; and of thy sweetest self (her famous Panderess) open I say. Sister? you hear me well, paint not your Tomb without; we know too well what rotten carcasses are lodged within; open I say.
sp.stage: Ero opens, and he sees her head laid on the coffin, etc.
sp.p: Sister I have brought you tidings to wake you out of this sleeping mummery.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Alas she is faint, and speech is painful to her.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Well said frubber, was there no Soldier here lately?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: A Soldier? when?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: This night, last night, the other night; and I know not how many nights and days.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Your brother Mistress, that asks if there were not a soldier here.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Here was no soldier.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yes Mistress I think here was such a one though you took no heed of him.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
Go to sister; did not you join kisses, embraces, and plight indeed with him, the utmost pledge of Nuptial love with him. Deny it, deny it; but
first hear me a short story. The Soldier was your disguised husband, dispute it not. That you see yonder, is but a shadow, an empty chest containing nothing but air. Stand not to gaze at it, it is true. This was a project of his own contriving to put your loyalty and constant vows to the test; you are warned, be armed.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: O fie on these perils.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O Ero! we are undone.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Nay, you would never be warned; I ever wished you to withstand the push of that Soldiers pike, and not enter him too deep into your bosom, but to keep sacred your widows vows made to Lysander.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Thou didst, thou didst.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Now you may see the event. Well our safety lies in our speed: he will do us mischief, if we prevent not his coming. Let us to your Mothers: and there call out your mightiest friends to guard you from his fury. Let them begin the quarrel with him for practising, this villainy on your sex to entrap your frailties.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Nay I resolve to sit out one brunt more; to try to what aim he will enforce his project: were he some other man, unknown to me, his violence might awe me; but knowing him as I do, I fear him not. Do thou but second me, thy strength and mine shall master his best force, if he should prove outrageous. Despair they say makes cowards turn courageous. Shut up the Tomb.

div1.stage: Shut the Tomb. Enter one of the Soldiers sent out before to seek the Sentinel.

sp.p: All pains are lost in hunting out this Soldier; his fear (adding wings to his heels) outgoes us as far as the fresh Hare the tired hounds. Who goes there?
A friend.
O, your success and mine touching this Sentinel, tells, I suppose, one tale; he is far enough I undertake by this time.
I blame him not: the law is severe (though just and cannot be dispensed.)

Why should the laws of Paphos, with more rigour, than other City laws pursue offenders? that not appeased with their lives forfeit, exact a justice of them after death? And if a Soldier in his watch forsooth lose one of the dead bodies, he must die for it: It seems the State needed no soldiers when that was made a law.

So we may chide the fire for burning us; or say the Bee is not good because she stings; It is not the body the law respects, but the soldiers neglect; when the watch (the guard and safety of the City) is left abandoned to all hazards. But let him go; and tell me if your news sort with mine, for Lycius; apprehended they say, about Lysanders murther.

It is true; he is at the Captains lodge under guard, and it is my charge in the morning to unclose the leaden coffin, and discover the body; The Captain will assay an old conclusion often approved; that at the murtherers sight the blood revives again, and boils afresh; and every wound has a condemning voice to cry out guilty against the murtherer.
O world, if this be true; his dearest friend, his bed companion, whom of all his friends he culled out for his bosom!

Tush man, in this topsy turvy world, friendship and bosom kindness, are but made covers for mischief, means to compass ill. Near-allied trust, is but a bridge for treason. The presumptions cry loud against him; his answers found disjointed; cross-legged tripping up one another. He names a Town whether he brought Lysander murthered by Mountaineers, that is false, some of the dwellers have been here, and all disclaim it. Besides, the wounds he bears in show, are such as shrews closely give their husbands, that never bleed, and find to be counterfeit.
O that jade falsehood is never sound of all; but halts of one leg still. Truth pace is all upright; sound everywhere.
sp.l: And like a die, sets ever on a square.
And how is Lycus his bearing in this condition?

sp.p: Faith (as the manner of such desperate offenders is till it come to the point) careless, and confident, laughing at all that seem to pity him. But leave it to the event. Night fellow Soldier, you will not meet me in the morning at the Tomb, and lend me your hand to the unrigging of Lysanders hearse.
I care not if I do, to view heavens power in this unbottomed seller.
sp.l: Blood, though it sleep a time, yet never dies.
The Gods on murtherers fix revengeful eyes.

div1.stage: Exeunt Lysander solus with a crow of iron, and a halter which he lays down and puts on his disguise again.

sp.l: Come my borrowed disguise, let me once more
Be reconciled to thee, my trustiest friend;
Thou that in truest shape hast let me see
That which my truer self hath hid from me,
Help me to take revenge on a disguise,
Ten times more false and counterfeit than thou.
Thou, false in show, hast been most true to me;
The seeming true; hath proved more false than her.
Assist me to behold this act of lust,
Note with a Scene of strange impiety.
Her husbands murthered corse! O more than horror!
I will not believe it untried; If she but lift
A hand to act it; by the fates her brains fly out,
Since she has madded me; let her beware my horns.
For though by goring her, no hope be shown
To cure myself, yet I will not bleed alone.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: The soldier; open.
See sweet, here are the engines that must do it,
Which with much fear of my discovery
I have at last procured.
Shall we about this work? I fear
the morn Will overtake us; my stay hath been prolonged
With hunting obscure nooks for these employments,
The night prepares away; Come, art resolved.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Aye, you shall find me constant.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Aye, so I have , most prodigiously constant,
Here is a rare halter to hug him with.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Better you and I join our hands and bear him thither, you take his head.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Aye, for that was always heavier than his whole body besides

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: You can tell best that loaded it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I will be at the feet; I am able to bear against you I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Hast thou prepared weak nature to digest
A sight so much distasteful; hast seared thy heart
It bleed not at the bloody spectacle?
Hast armed thy fearful eyes against the affront
Of such a direful object?
Thy murthered husband ghastly staring on thee;
His wounds gaping to affright thee; his body soiled with
Gore? fore heaven my heart shrugs at it.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: So does not mine,
Love is resolute; and stands not to consult
With petty terror; but in full carrier
Runs blindfold through an Army of misdoubts,
And interposing fears; perhaps I will weep
Or so, make a forced face and laugh again.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O most valiant love !
I was thinking with myself as I came; how if this
Brake to light; his body known;
(As many notes might make it) would it not fix
Upon thy fame, an unremoved Brand
Of shame, and hate; they that in former times
Adored thy virtue; would they not abhor
Thy loathest memory?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: All this I know.
But yet my love to thee
Swallows all this; or whatsoever, doubts
Can come against it.
Shame is but a feather balanced with thy love .

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Neither fear nor shame? you are steel to the
Proof (but I shall iron you): Come then let us to work.
Alas poor Corps how many martyrdoms
Must thou endure? mangled by me a villain,
And now exposed to foul shame of the Gibbet?
Fore, piety, there is somewhat in me strives
Against the deed, my very arm relents
To strike a stroke so inhuman,
To wound a hallowed hearse? Suppose it were mine,
Would not my Ghost start up and fly upon thee?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: No, I would mall it down again with this.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Nay, then I will assay my strength; a Soldier and afraid of a dead man? A soft rode milk-sop? come I will do it myself.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And I look on? give me the iron.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: No, I will not lose the glory of it. This hand, etc.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pray thee sweet, let it not be said the savage act was thine; deliver me the engine.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Content yourself, it is in a fitter hand.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Wilt thou first? art not thou the most.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Ill destined wife of a transformed monster;
Who to assure himself of what he knew,
Hath lost the shape of man.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Ha? cross-capers?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.l: Poor Soldiers case; do not we know you Sir?
But I have given thee what thou camest to seek.
Go Satyr, run affrighted with the noise
Of that harsh sounding horn thyself hast blown,
Farewell; I leave thee there my Husbands Corps, Make much of that.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What have I done? O let me lie and grieve, and speak no more.

div1.stage: Captain, Lycus with a guard of three or four Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Bring him away; you must have patience Sir: If you can say aught to quit you of those presumptions that lie heavy on you, you shall be heard. If not, it is not your braves, nor your affecting looks can carry it.
We must acquit our duties.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: You are Captain of the watch Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You take me right.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: So were you best do me ; see your presumptions be strong; or be assured that shall prove a dear presumption, to brand me with the murther of my friend. But you have been suborned by some close villain to defame me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: It will not be so put off friend Lycus, I could wish your soul as free from taint of this foul fact; as mine from any such unworthy practise.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Conduct me to the Governor himself; to confront before him your shallow accusations.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
First Sir, I will bear you to Lysanders Tomb, to confront
the murthered body; and see what evidence the wounds will yield against you.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: You are wise Captain. But if the body should chance not to speak; If the wounds should be tongue tied Captain; where is then your evidence Captain? will you not be laughed at for an officious Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You are gallant Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Your Captainship commands my service no further.

sp.speaker: Cap.
Lyc.
sp.p: Say you so Captain? but hark you Captain, Might it not concur with the quality of your office, ere this matter grow to the height of a more threatening danger; to wink a little at a by-slip, or so?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: To send a man abroad under guard of one of your silliest shack-rags; that he may beat the knave, and run his way. I mean this on good terms Captain; I will be thankful.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I will think on it hereafter. Mean time I have other employment for you.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Your place is worthily replenished Captain. My duty Sir; Hark Captain, there is a mutiny in your Army; I will go raise the Governor.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No haste Sir; he will soon be here without your summons.

div1.stage: Soldiers thrust up Lysander from the Tomb.

sp.p: Bring forth the Knight of the Tomb; have we met with you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pray thee soldier use thine office with better temper.

sp.l: Come convey him to the Lord Governor,
sp.p: First afore the Captain Sir. Have the heavens nought else to do, but to stand still, and turn all their malignant Aspects upon one man?
Captain here is the Sentinel we sought for; he is some new pressed Soldier, for none of us know him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Where found you him?
My truant was mitched Sir into a blind corner of the Tomb.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well said, guard him safe, but for the Corps.

For the Corps Sir? bare misprision, there is no body, nothing. A mere blandation; a deceptio visus. Unless this soldier
for hunger have eat up Lysanders body.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Why, I could have told you this before Captain; The body was borne away piecemeal by devout Ladies of Venus order, for the man died one of Venus Martys. And yet I heard since it was seen whole on the other side the downs upon a Cowl-staff betwixt two huntsmen, to feed their dogs withal. Which was a miracle Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Mischief in this act hath a deep bottom; and requires more time to sound it. But you Sir, it seems, are a Soldier of the newest stamp. Know you what it is to forsake your stand? There is one of the bodies in your charge stolen away; how answer you that? See here comes the Governor.

div1.stage: Enter a Guard bare after the Governor: Tharsalio, Argus, Clinias, before Eudora, Cynthia, Laodice, Sthenio, Ianthe, Ero, etc.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Stand aside there.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Room for a strange Governor. The perfect draught of a most brainless, imperious upstart. O desert! where wert thou, when this wooden dagger was gilded over with the Title of Governor?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Peace Masters; hear my Lord.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: All wisdom be silent; Now speaks Authority.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: I am come in person to discharge Justice.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Of his office.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: The cause you shall know hereafter; and it is this. A villain, whose very sight I abhor; where is he? Let me see him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is it Lycus you mean my Lord?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Go to sirrah you are too malapert; I have heard of your Sentinels escape; look to it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My Lord, this is the Sentinel you speak of.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: How now Sir? what time of day is it?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: I cannot show you precisely, if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: What? shall we have replications? Rejoinders?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Such a creature, Fool is, when he bestrides the back of Authority.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Sirrah, stand you forth. It is supposed thou hast committed a most inconvenient murther upon the body of Lysander.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: My good Lord, I have not.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Peace varlet; dost chop with me? I say it is imagined thou hast murthered Lysander. How it will be proved I know not. Thou shalt therefore presently be had to execution, as justice in such cases requireth. Soldiers take him away: bring forth the Sentinel.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: Your Lordship will first let my defence be heard.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p:
Sirrah; I will no sending nor proving. For my part I am satisfied, it is so: that is enough for thee. I had ever a Sympathy
in my mind against him.
sp.l: Let him be had away.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: A most excellent apprehension. He is able ye see to judge of a cause at first sight, and hear but two parties. Here is a second Solon.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Hear him my Lord; presumptions oftentimes,
(Though likely grounded) reach not to the truth.
And Truth is oft abused by likelihood.
Let him be heard my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Madam, content yourself. I will do justice; I will not hear him. Your late Lord, was my Honourable Predecessor; But your Ladyship must pardon me. In matters of justice I am blind.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: I know no persons. If a Court favourite write to me in a case of justice: I will pocket his letter, and proceed. If a Suitor in a case of justice thrusts a bribe into my hand, I will pocket his bribe, and proceed. Therefore Madam, set your heart at rest: I am seated in the Throne of justice; and I will do justice; I will not hear him.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Not hear him my Lord?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: No my Lady: and moreover put you in mind, in whose presence you stand; if you Parrot to me long; go to.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Nay the Vice must snap his Authority at all he meets, how shalt else be known what part he plays?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Your husband was a Noble Gentleman, but Alas he came short, he was no Statesman. He has left a foul City behind him.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Aye, and I can tell you it will trouble his Lordship and all his Honourable assistants of Scavengers to sweep it clean.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: It is full of vices, and great ones too.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And thou none of the meanest.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: But I will turn all topsy turvy; and set up a new discipline amongst you. I will cut off all perished members.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: That is the Surgeons office.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Cast out these rotten stinking carcasses for infecting the whole City.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Rotten they may be, but their wenches use to pepper them; and their Surgeons to parboil them; and that preserves them from stinking, if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Peace Sirrah, peace; and yet it is well said too. A good pregnant fellow in faith. But to proceed. I will spew drunkenness out on the City.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Into the Country.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p:
Shifters shall cheat and starve; And no man shall do good but where there is no need. Braggarts shall live at the head; and the tumult that haunt Taverns. Asses shall bear good qualities, and wise men shall use them. I will whip lechery out of the City, there shall be no more Cuckolds. They that heretofore were errand Cornutos, shall now be honest shopkeepers, and justice shall take place. I will hunt jealousy
out of my Dominion.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Do hear Brother?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: It shall be the only note of love to the husband, to love the wife: And none shall be more kindly welcome to him than he that cuckolds him.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Believe it a wholesome reformation.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: I will have no more Beggars. Fools shall have wealth, and the learned shall live by their wits. I will have no more Bankrupts. They that owe money shall pay it at their best leisure: And the rest shall make a virtue of imprisonment; and their wives shall help to pay their debts. I will have all young widows spaded for marrying again. For the old and withered, they shall be confiscate to unthrifty Gallants, and decayed Knights. If they be poor they shall be burnt to make soap ashes, or given to Surgeons Hall, to be stamped to salve for the French measels. To conclude, I will Cart pride out of the Town.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: If it please your Honour Pride if it be never so beggarly will look for a Coach.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Well said on mine Honour. A good significant fellow in faith: What is he? he talks much; does he follow your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: No if it please your Honour, I go before her.

sp.speaker: Gouer,
sp.p: A good undertaking presence; A well-promising forehead, your Gentleman Usher Madam?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Yours if you please my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Borne in the City?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Aye if it please your Honour, but begot in the Court.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Trestle-legged?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Aye, if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: The better, it bears a breadth; makes room on both sides. Might I not see his pace?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.p: Yes if it please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p:
It is well, it is very well. Give me thy hand: Madam I
will accept this property at your hand, and will wear it threadbare for your sake. Fall in there, sirrah. And for the matter of Lycus Madam, I must tell you, you are shallow: there is a State point in it? hark you: The Viceroy has given him, and we must uphold correspondence. He must walk; say one man goes wrongfully out of the world, there are hundreds to one come wrongfully into the world.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Your Lordship will give me but a word in private.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Come brother; we know you well: what means this habit? why staid you not at Dipolis as you resolved, to take advertisement for us of your wives bearing?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: O brother, this jealous frenzy has borne me headlong to ruin.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Go to, be comforted; uncase yourself; and discharge your friend.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: Is that Lysander say you? And is all his story true? By our lady Madam this jealousy will cost him dear: he undertook the person of a Soldier; and as a Soldier must have justice. Madam, his Altitude in this case cannot dispense. Lycus, this Soldier hath acquitted you.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: And that acquittal I will for him requite; the body lost, is by this time restored to his place.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: It is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: These are State points, in which your Lordships time has not yet trained your Lordship; please your Lordship to grace a Nuptial we have now in hand.
sp.l: Twixt this young Lady and this Gentleman.
Your Lordship there shall hear the ample story.
And how the Ass wrapped in a Lions skin
Fearfully roared, but his large ears appeared
And made him laughed at, that before was feared.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: I will go with you. For my part, I am at a non plus.

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p: Come brother; Thank the Countess: she hath sweat to make your peace. Sister give me your hand.
sp.l: So, Brother let your lips compound the strife,
And think you have the only constant Wife.
